          "content": "# Following an action card\n \nWant to be informed about changes to an action? Click 'Follow' to receive notifications of each change.\n Written by Erin Gouveia Updated over 3 years ago \nNow, you can keep track of any action in Hive.¬†\n\nWhen you follow an action, you receive notifications for all changes made to the card.¬†\n\nYou become a follower of an action card if you: \n \nCreate the card\n \n‚Ä¢ \nAre assigned to the action card\n \n‚Ä¢ \nAre @ mentioned in a comment\n \n‚Ä¢ \nComment on the card \n \n‚Ä¢ \nClick 'Follow' \n \nYou can also choose who you want to follow this card by clicking '+' and choosing their name from user dropdown list. \n\n Unfollowing an action card **\n\nIf you no longer want to receive updates on an action card, you can select 'Unfollow'.\n\nYou can also unfollow on behalf of other users - the same way you can follow on their behalf! Click '+' next to the number of users following, deselect the users you no longer wish to receive updates and click 'Update followers' \n\n**Mass follow or unfollow action cards **\n\nIf you have a list of action cards that you need to follow or unfollow, you can switch to Table view and select the action cards from the table. Once selected, right click and choose your option. This is the easiest and fastest way to mass follow or unfollow action cards! \n\n Related Articles Meet the Hive action card How do I find archived action cards? New This Week in Hive: August 2021 New This Week in Hive: September 2021 New This Week in Hive: November 2021  üòû üòê üòÉ \n‚Ä¢ Sign In \n‚Ä¢ Forgot Password? \n‚Ä¢ API \n‚Ä¢ \n‚Ä¢",
          "char_count": 1539
        },
        {
          "title": "Action Card History",
          "url": "https://help.hive.com/en/articles/3843678-action-card-history",
          "content": "Action Card History | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢    Using Hive Action Cards Action Card History \n# Action Card History\n \nView an audit history of changes to Action Cards\n Written by Andrew Naisawald Updated over 3 years ago \nDo you ever see the status of an action card change and wonder who on your team made the change and when? Or ask when sub-actions were created and assigned?\n\nWith Action Card History, now you can view an audit log of card changes! Wonder no more about the following types of changes:\n \nCreated Date\n \n‚Ä¢ \nStatus Changes\n \n‚Ä¢ \nAction Assignments\n \n‚Ä¢ \nCreation of Sub-Actions\n \n‚Ä¢ \nTime Estimates\n \n‚Ä¢ \nDue Dates\n \n‚Ä¢ \nApproval Requests and Decisions\n \n‚Ä¢ \nLabels being added\n \n‚Ä¢ \nAttachment added\n \nView the Action History in the bottom left of the action card, where you'll see \"Show history\".\n\n Gain a better understanding of action cards progression and changes through Action History! ‚Äã\n Related Articles Following an action card Recent Action Card Reference Meet the Hive action card Action card date sync Manage All Your Action Card Statuses in the Status Library  üòû üòê üòÉ \n‚Ä¢ Sign In \n‚Ä¢ Forgot Password? \n‚Ä¢ API \n‚Ä¢ \n‚Ä¢",
          "char_count": 1124
        },
        {
          "title": "Action Card Priorities",
          "url": "https://help.hive.com/en/articles/4600441-action-card-priorities",
          "content": "Action card priorities | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢ **     Using Hive Action Cards Action card priorities \n# Action card priorities\n \nAdaptable to how your team works: create, set & sort your priorities\n Written by Erin Gouveia Updated over 5 months ago  \nOne of the most requested features on our Feature Request page was the ability to set priority on action cards, and we're excited to announce that it's here - thank you for using your voice, Hive Community! \n\nWith priority levels on your action cards, you can now:\n \nSee a priority level indicator on the outside of cards in any project's card ** layout - aka, Status, Team or Label View\n \n‚Ä¢ \nCreate a customized priority list - including colors! (Is your team more Low, Medium, High? Or perhaps P1, P2, P3, P4? - it's your choice!) \n \n‚Ä¢ \nSort action cards by Priority level in your project's card layouts\n\n# How to get started: Toggle on the Hive App\n \n**Step 1: **Toggle on Card priorities in Hive Apps. Note: A workspace Admin must enable this! \n\n**Step 2: **Check out your new feature: open any action card to see the defaults: High, Medium and Low as shown in the screenshot below. If that works for you, you're all set! If you'd like to customize it, continue reading to the next section. \n\n# Customize your Priorities\n \nWe recommend starting by using the edit option to change the name & color of the 3 existing priorities and adding a fourth or more using the \"Add a new priority level' option. Click the Edit pencil when hovering over the priority to get started:\n\n You can customize:\n \n‚Ä¢ \nName \n \n‚Ä¢ \nLevel (when you sort, 1 will be at the top)\n \n‚Ä¢ \nColor\n\n# View & Sort your Priorities:\n \n## Card Layouts\n \nFrom a card layout, click **Filters,** and then under Sort's **Order by** drop-down, choose Priority Level. The cards will be ordered with Level 1 at the top, descending from there.\n\n## Priority Levels & Urgency\n \nWhen sorted by Priority Level, if you have an action card marked as Urgent, the Urgent card will be ranked at the top, even if its Priority Level is lower than another card. After the Urgent card, the rest of the cards will be listed by their Priority Level (and cannot be re-ordered differently). \n\n## **Table View**\n \nFrom Table view, show the Priority column and then click on the top of the column to sort in Priority order:**‚Äã\n\n# Common Questions\n\n## Q: Are priorities workspace-wide? Will they be the same on ALL action cards in the workspace? **\n \nA: Once toggled on, Card Priorities will be shown on **all** action cards across the workspace and will appear the **same** in the drop-down list across all action cards & projects. \n\n## ** Q: Can I see priorities in Table View? What about sorting by Priority in Table View? **\n \nA: Yes! Priority is now a column in Table view, and you may sort and filter based on this column. \n\n## Q: I have an enhancement request for this feature, how can I share it? \n \nA: We would love to hear from you! Not sure if we have implemented your request yet? Here are some potential ways to expand upon this feature ** that are not yet implemented **:\n \n‚Ä¢ \nShow Priority level icon on subaction rows\n \n‚Ä¢ \nShow Priority level icon in My Actions view & make the Priority sort sync up to the new Priority level (currently it still is related to the manual rank)\n \n‚Ä¢ \nAdd record of priority change to action card history\n \nGo ahead and tell us what you would like to see below: \n\n Send us a suggestion \n\n Related Articles Resourcing Link Jira to your Action Card or Project Meet the Hive action card Supercharge your Ad Ops work queue New This Week in Hive: August 2021  üòû üòê üòÉ \n‚Ä¢ Sign In \n‚Ä¢ Forgot Password? \n‚Ä¢ API \n‚Ä¢ \n‚Ä¢",
          "char_count": 3627

          "title": "Recent Action Card Reference",
          "url": "https://help.hive.com/en/articles/2273647-recent-action-card-reference",
          "content": "Recent Action Card Reference | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢    Using Hive Action Cards Recent Action Card Reference \n# Recent Action Card Reference\n \nKeep track of your recently opened action cards\n Written by Andrew Naisawald Updated over 3 years ago \n\"I've forgotten what action card I was working on previously!\"\n\nDoes this ever happen to you?¬†\n\nFret not, Hive is here to help. With Recent Action Card Reference, you can now view a list of your recently viewed actions.¬†\n\nNote:¬†\n \nIn order for Recent Action Card Reference to work, you must have recently viewed an action card¬†\n \n‚Ä¢ \nRecent Action Card Reference will keep track of your 10 most recent actions viewed\n\nToggle open the action history panel by hitting the highlighted History icon in the bottom right. To close it, hit the icon again.\n\n‚Ä¢ \nTip: Press \"H\" to expand and collapse the recently viewed panel\n \nNever lose track of your work again!\n Related Articles 4 Ways to quickly access your \"actions\" Action Card History Meet the Hive action card Action card priorities How do I find archived action cards?  üòû üòê üòÉ \n‚Ä¢ Sign In \n‚Ä¢ Forgot Password? \n‚Ä¢ API \n‚Ä¢ \n‚Ä¢",

        {
          "title": "Comments on Actions",
          "url": "https://help.hive.com/en/articles/1517071-comment-on-actions-and-sub-actions",
          "content": "# Comment on actions and sub-actions\n \nComment directly on action cards to make sure the communication surrounding your tasks doesn‚Äôt get lost in the shuffle.\n A Written by Alexander Heldring Updated over a year ago  \n## Posting a Comment\n \nTo add a new comment, simply type your message in the ‚ÄúAdd a comment‚Äù bar towards the bottom of the action card and click ‚ÄúPost‚Äù (or press ‚ÄúCommand+ Enter‚Äù).\n\n## @ Mention Specific Teammates\n \nYou can address your comment to a specific teammate by @ mentioning them within the comment. Start by typing the \"@\" symbol immediately followed by the first few characters of their name, to select them. They will receive a notification once the comment has been posted.\n\n## @ Mention Action Card Followers\n \nBy typing \"@action\", a direct notification will be sent to all followers of the action card, without you have to individually tag them.\n\n## @ Mention All Project Members\n \nBy typing \"@project\", a direct notification will be sent to all project members. \n\n## Attaching Files\n \nIf you need to include a file in your comment, you can easily add an attachment by clicking the paperclip icon. Attachments that are added with comments will also be uploaded to the attachments section of the action card.\n\n## Editing or Deleting Comments\n \nIf you want to edit one of your comments, just hover over the comment, click the pencil icon, and make the appropriate changes. Don‚Äôt forget to click ‚ÄúSave Changes.‚Äù ‚Äã\n \nTo delete one of your comments, hover over it and click on the trash can icon. \n\nOnly the comment writer may delete or edit comments. \n\n## Spell check\n \nIf you make a mistake when typing a comment, Hive will let you know about it by highlighting the word with red dots beneath it. You will then be able to correct it manually or right-click it and select the correct word from the available options. You can also let Hive learn the spelling if it's actually not a mistake so that it doesn't get \"flagged\" to you in the future. \n\n## Read/Unread Comments\n \nTo see if any comments are left unread, navigate to Table View and enable the 'Comments' column. An orange comment bubble will appear when there is an unread comment for your action card. This makes it super easy for you to stay up to date with any new comments and ensure you never miss a thing. Managing your work just got a whole lot more convenient! ‚Äã\n\n## Sort comments by date\n \nClick 'Sort' to switch the order of comments and show the newest comments at the top or vice versa (chronologically).\n\n Related Articles Following an action card Integrate your file storage with Hive Create a Jira issue from Hive Meet the Hive action card New This Week in Hive: September 2021  üòû üòê üòÉ Sign In \n‚Ä¢ Forgot Password? \n‚Ä¢ API \n‚Ä¢ \n‚Ä¢",
          "char_count": 2726
        },
        {
          "title": "Action Templates",
          "url": "https://help.hive.com/en/articles/62919-action-templates",
          "content": "Action templates | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢ **     Using Hive Action Cards Action templates \n# Action templates\n \nUpdate action details in just a few clicks using templates\n Written by Erin Gouveia Updated over 5 months ago  \nYou can create action templates to easily add subactions, assignees, due dates, and dependencies to your action cards. Action templates can help you quickly update tasks that tend to repeat throughout your projects and keep consistency across the workspace.\n \nAdditionally, these templates can also be automatically applied using forms or project settings for more streamlined workflows.\n\n# To create an action template:\n \nGo to your main menu (upper right corner)\n \n‚Ä¢ \nClick \"Settings\"\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSelect \"Templates\"\n \n‚Ä¢ \nMake sure you are in the \"Action Card\" menu\n \n‚Ä¢ \nClick \"Create action template\"\n \n‚Ä¢ \nName the template and provide a label if desired\n \n‚Ä¢ \nAdd the subactions, assignees, days, and durations. It will look something like the below. You can add further levels of subactions onto your action templates too!\n \nThen you just save the action template and you're done!\n \n You can also create an action template straight from an action card, using the 'Save as template' option underneath the More menu on the right:\n\n# Setting due dates on action templates\n \nTo ensure deadlines are included when you apply an action template, make sure that the 'Automatically add due dates' option is checked. ‚Äã\n \n We will refer to the image above for the examples below \n\nAssuming you've used positive and negative deadlines, there are two different scenarios to which deadlines will be applied:\n\n## 1. If your main action card already has a deadline set, at the moment that you apply the action template:\n \nSince you have already applied the deadline to the action, Hive is smart to know that you need to complete the action by that specific date. Hive will set any subaction in your action template that is listed as 'Day 0' as equal** to the parent action due date.¬†\n\nAll negative days will happen before the action due date and all positive days will happen after the action due date, following the same pattern.\n\nUsing the above example for the Blog Post action template, if you have **set** the action card's deadline to 15 Jan **before** applying the template, when you apply the Blog Post action template:\n \n‚Ä¢ \n\"Draft\" will be set for 13 Jan (minus 2 days before 15 Jan)¬†\n \n‚Ä¢ \n\"Review\" will be set for 14 Jan (minus 1 day before 15 Jan)\n \n‚Ä¢ \n\"Finalize & Post\" will be set for 15 Jan (Day 0)\n \n‚Ä¢ \n\"Analyze Post Traffic\" will be set for 21 Jan (plus 6 days after 15 Jan)\n \n## 2. If your action does not currently have a deadline set when you apply the action template:\n \nSince you have enabled deadlines and your action currently has no deadline, Hive assumes that the subaction marked as 'Day 0' in the action template is today.\n\nUsing the above example for the Blog Post action template, if today is 17 Dec:\n \n‚Ä¢ \n\"Draft\" will be set for 15 Dec (minus 2 days before today)\n \n‚Ä¢ \n\"Review\" will be set for 16 Dec (minus 1 day before today)\n \n‚Ä¢ \n\"Finalize & Post\" will be set for 17 Dec (today)\n \n‚Ä¢ \n\"Analyze Post Traffic\" will be set for 23 Dec (6 days after today)\n\n# Adding dependencies to the template\n \nNot only can you automatically add deadlines, you can also set up dependencies . So if one step can't move forward without the completion of another, it can be useful to set one up.¬†\n\nJust click the \"Add dependency\" link. It will open a search box where you type the name of the step you want this step to be dependent on and select add. It will then show the dependency in bright yellow with the option to remove.¬†\n\n# Adding approval rounds to the template\n \nIf your action will need an approval process, you can include an approval template within your action template. ( Note: you will need to first save the approval template by setting up the approval round and clicking Save as template under the More menu ).\n\nOnce you have the approval template, you can add it to your action template here towards the bottom of the modal.\n\n# Adding an action template to a card\n \nBefore applying an action template, you can also manually create action cards. Navigate to the project workspace, click on the **New (+)** button in the toolbar, and customize your action card for the specific needs of your project.\n \nClick the blue + New button next to the search bar to create a new action card, then select \"Apply Template\" under the More menu towards the right.\n\nFrom the searchable popup, click the name of the template you would like to apply. It will create the subactions and add the assignees, due dates, and dependencies from your template.\n\n# Adding multiple action templates to a card\n \nYou can now layer multiple action templates on a single action card. To do so:\n \n‚Ä¢ \nApply the first action template to the card.¬†\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSelect a second action template from the dropdown list.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nHive will add in all of the subactions, due dates, assignees, and attachments from the second action template. All data from the first template will also remain!¬†\n \n# Applying action template to multiple actions at once\n \nIf you want to apply the same template to actions in bulk, you can do it in Table view. All you have to do is to select actions, right-click and select 'Apply action template'. \n \nAlternatively, action templates can be pre-applied to cards using the \"Use action template\" option in project settings. Configure this to automatically apply templates to new cards created via forms, ensuring consistency and saving time.\n\n Related Articles Action Template ‚Äî Deadlines New this Week in Hive: June 2021 New This Week in Hive: August 2021 New This Week in Hive: November 2021 New This Week in Hive: December 2021  üòû üòê üòÉ \n‚Ä¢ Sign In \n‚Ä¢ Forgot Password? \n‚Ä¢ API \n‚Ä¢ \n‚Ä¢",

    "project_views": {
      "feature_name": "Project Views & Layouts",
      "description": "7 interchangeable views: Status View (Kanban boards), Label View (tag-based grouping), Calendar View (date-based), Gantt View (timeline with dependencies), Table View (spreadsheet-like), Team View (by assignee), List View (filterable list with sections).",
      "article_count": 2,
      "total_content_chars": 13445,
      "articles": [
        {
          "title": "Project Layouts (All 6 Views)",
          "url": "https://help.hive.com/en/articles/511650-project-layouts",
          "content": "Project layouts | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢ **     Using Hive Projects Project layouts \n# Project layouts\n \nThe 7 types of layouts and when you should use each\n Written by Erin Gouveia Updated over a year ago  \nHive offers 7 different ways to view a Hive project and this will give you an overview of each:\n \n Status view \n \n‚Ä¢ \n Team view \n \n‚Ä¢ \n Calendar \n \n‚Ä¢ \n Label view \n \n‚Ä¢ \n Gantt chart \n \n‚Ä¢ \n Table view \n \n‚Ä¢ \n List view \n \nWithin the project, you can toggle between the views at any time** and even have **multiple people in the same project each working in a different layout**. Everyone will see the information and **updates in real-time, no matter which layout** they are in!\n\nEach layout can be helpful depending on what your team is working on and how you like to organize your work.¬† So how do you know which one to choose?\n\nIn this article, we'll provide guidance on the pros and cons of each layout. So that the next time you make a project you can choose your layout with confidence.¬†\n\n# **1. Status view**\n \n In status view, all of your project's action cards are organized in lists that each represent a \"status\" in your workflow. Your actions move horizontally across the lists from unstarted to completed. You can customize the status columns to fit your team's exact specifications. \n\n**When is status view helpful?**\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIf you prefer a **visual workflow**, status view lets you see at a glance the progress of a project.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIf the actions in your project **all go through the same statuses**, it makes a lot of sense to use a status view.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIf your team uses **Agile methods**, status view is best suited to organizing and managing sprints.\n \nThose are just a few of the instances status view can be useful. In terms of downsides, status view doesn't emphasize deadlines as much as other views, and it can be a little more difficult to break it down by team member or label.¬†\n\n**A note on statuses:**\n\nAs mentioned above, actions in status view move horizontally from one list to another. The default set of statuses is unstarted -> in progress -> completed. However, you can add new statuses to completely customize how your project is organized. The easiest way to add a status is to scroll over to the right of your project, add the name of your status in the text box, and press enter.\n\nHere are some examples of sets of statuses that your team could use:\n \n‚Ä¢ \n**Blog publishing** - unstarted -> ideas -> writing -> editing -> add images -> published -> share on social media -> completed\n \n‚Ä¢ \n**Agile sprint** - unstarted -> this week -> in progress -> needs review -> completed\n \n‚Ä¢ \n**Hiring funnel **- unstarted -> reviewed application -> selected for phone interview -> phone interview scheduled -> selected for on-site interview -> on-site interview scheduled -> hired -> completed\n\n# **2. Team view**\n \n In team view, all your actions are organized under columns with each list representing a team member. ¬†You can reassign actions to other team members with a simple drag and drop, and add new actions onto someone's list with ease. \n\n**When is team view helpful?**\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIt's great for managers who want an easy way to **assess team workload**.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIf actions often move from one person to another, it is super **easy to move actions between team members** in team view.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nYou can keep from putting too much on people's list by **adding tasks to the unassigned** column. That way the first person to have some free time can pick it up by dragging it onto their list.¬†\n \nThese are just a few reasons of why having a team view can help you move your project forward.\n\nTeam view is not as helpful if you need to see the status of your actions or if you are working on a project by yourself.\n\n# **3. Calendar view**\n \n In calendar view , you can see all the actions in your project organized by deadline. You can simply drag and drop to change an action's deadline. The default view shows all actions due for the next six weeks. \n\n Hive calendar also allows you to **one-way sync **to Google Calendar, Outlook, and iCal. \n\n**When is calendar view helpful?**\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIf you want your team to **focus on deadlines**, a calendar makes it easy to keep them top of mind.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIf you want to be able to **view your actions on your email calendar **as well, this view is the only one that allows you to do that.¬†\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIf you want **all the actions you add to have deadlines**, it's super easy to do on the calendar. You can just click the date and it automatically opens a task with that deadline.¬†\n \nCalendar view is awesome! The only cases where it's not as useful are when you want to be able to view key details of your actions on the front of the card. In calendar view, only the title and the assignee of the action shows. It's also harder to see who on your team is working on what for the same reason.¬†\n\n# **4. Label view**\n \n In label view, all your actions are organized under lists with each list representing a different label. ¬†You can change the label of an action with a simple drag and drop, and add new actions to a label with ease. \n\nLabels in Hive are essential tags you can add to action cards that make it easier to distinguish between different actions in a project.¬†\n\n**When is label view helpful?**\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIf your **team uses several labels**, this layout can be a great way to assess your workflow across initiatives.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIf you want to **easily add labels to new actions **you create, all you have to do is type in an action in the text box of the label you want to add.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIf your team prefers a **visual workflow**, it helps that each action comes with a color that can make it easier spot the differences between them.\n \nLabel view is not as helpful if your team doesn't really use labels or you want to be able to easily see who is responsible for an action.¬†\n\n# **5. Gantt Chart**\n \n In Gantt, all your actions are laid out in a chart where each line represents something you want to do. These actions correspond to dates where the start and endpoint of the action represents the timeline it is expected to be completed. You can drag and drop to change the timeline and simply click to add a new action.¬† \n\nGantt charts includes the ability to zoom into to take a closer look and add dependencies when needed.\n\n**When is Gantt Chart helpful?**\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIf you are trying to plan out how long a project will take, Gantt is a perfect way to assess that.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIf you have a clear understanding of the steps involved in completing the goal, it is really easy to lay out in a chart form.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIf you need to be able to share your plan with people outside your organization, Gantt allows you to export your work to PDF, PNG or XLS.\n \nGantt view is so great for planning, but not as useful if you run in an agile framework where you never really can predict specific timelines.\n\n# **6. Table View**\n \n In Table View, all your actions are laid out in a table (like a spreadsheet). These actions can be sorted and filtered accordingly to your needs and preferences. You can easily edit the text or change the fields by clicking on it.¬† \n \n \"\n \n Additionally, you can use filters on the column titles to filter many of the actions.           "content": "List View: A New Project View in Hive | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢ **     Using Hive Projects List View: A New Project View in Hive \n# List View: A New Project View in Hive\n Written by Michaela Rollings Updated over 4 months ago  \nThis week we're launching List View,** and it's not every day we launch a brand new project view. \n\nWith this new view, we're bringing the convenience of a list into your Hive projects - if you like Home View, this will be your new favorite.\n\nThink: one expanded list of all actions in your project that can be customized, filtered, and edited to fit your workflow, preferences, and needs. \n\n**‚Äã\n \nTo access List View and test it out for yourself, just create a new tab with our swanky new tabs feature and select List View. \n\nIf you want this List View to be private, just slide the \"Private view\" toggle on the bottom of the dropdown.\n\nAt the top right, you'll find the Configure view settings:**\n \n Group By section : by default, the List view will be organized by Status, but with a few clicks, you can configure the list view to group by:\n \nStatus\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSection\n \n‚Ä¢ \nPriority Level\n \n‚Ä¢ \nProject/subproject\n \n‚Ä¢ \nPhase\n \n‚Ä¢ \n Filter section: provides a variety of different filters such as Statuses, Assignees, Dates, Labels, etc.\n \n‚Ä¢ \n Display section: \n \nColumns: One of the ways to select which columns to display.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nBlocked actions: Blocked / Unblocked / Show both\n \n‚Ä¢ \nMilestones: Milestone / No Milestone / Show both\n \n‚Ä¢ \nArchived actions check box\n \n‚Ä¢ \nProjects in draft mode check box\n \n‚Ä¢ \nEmpty groups check box: if your Section/Project/Status, etc doesn't have any actions under it, you'll want to check this box to allow Hive to show that empty Section/Project/Status in your view.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nUnbundle subactions: Do not show subactions unless they're grouped under parent actions\n \n‚Ä¢ \nHide subactions: Do not show subactions when they're not grouped under parent actions\n \nBringing special attention to Sections.           "content": "Meet the Hive action card | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢ **    Getting Started Getting to know Hive Meet the Hive action card \n# Meet the Hive action card\n \nLearn the basics about action cards.\n A Written by Alexander Heldring Updated over 5 months ago \nThe action card is your home base for important details and collaboration. \n\nThe card makes it easy to quickly gather the most important details of any assignment. In the right column** you‚Äôll see who is assigned to the action, when it‚Äôs due, and what the card‚Äôs status is. \n\nIf you'd like the action card to appear as an event in your Google/Outlook Calendar, you can use the 'Schedule time' option under the Dates section in the card.           "content": "Project Navigator | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢ **     Using Hive Projects Project Navigator \n# Project Navigator\n \nNavigate between all of your active and archived projects\n Written by Erin Gouveia Updated over 7 months ago  \nProject Navigator makes it easy to view, edit, and access all of the projects you're working on.¬†\n\n## Accessing Project Navigator\n \nTo access the Project Navigator, click the 'Project Navigator' page from the left panel of the app.¬†\n\n## Using Project Navigator\n \nIt will open a panel that shows a list of all the projects you have been added to in Hive. If you're looking for a particular project, you can search for it using the search bar.\n\nIf you want to see which projects you're a member of, you should go to My Projects tab. \n\nYou can see certain project information at a glance and control which columns (like the name of each project, the team members involved, the status, start and end dates, budget and project custom fields) are displayed for each project. Use the 'Manage columns' button on the right-hand side of Project Navigator to control these columns. You can also sort the columns to make it easier for you to navigate through your projects.\n\nIf you need to filter your projects by a project custom field value, this is something you can do as well. You need to hover over a custom field column and click the Filter icon. Set your value and you'll get a list of matching projects.\n\nWhen you hover over a specific project, four options appear on the right (Tip: you may have to scroll over if you have many project custom fields!)\n\n Edit **- Change the settings of your project\n \n‚Ä¢ \n**Copy** - Create another project with all the same tasks and layout with all dates removed\n \n‚Ä¢ \n**Archive** - Remove project from action panel while still maintaining the data in the \"Archived\" section of Project Navigator\n \n‚Ä¢ \n**Delete** - Remove the project and all its tasks from the workspace (Can be recovered from the Trash bin during 30 days).\n \nIn addition to your Active Projects and My Projects, you can also access your Archived Projects, Summary Views, and Templates from Project Navigator.\n\nTo quickly perform an update, you can also right-click on the project row in the Project Navigator. This will allow you to easily:\n \n‚Ä¢ \nOpen the project in a new tab\n \n‚Ä¢ \nPin project\n \n‚Ä¢ \nArchive project\n \n‚Ä¢ \nDelete project\n\n## Pinning projects\n \nIf you are working in certain projects or summary views frequently, you can pin those to the left-hand bar. ¬†By doing so, you'll be able to easily access those projects from anywhere within Hive.\n\nTo pin a project, simply click the pushpin icon to the left of the project name. Click it again if you'd like to remove it from the favorites section.¬†\n\n# More Menu\n \nIf you want to drill into a project without navigating away from whatever view you are on, you can use the More Menu. It allows you to:\n \n‚Ä¢ \nOpen a project in a new tab \n \n‚Ä¢ \nUnpin the project from your left sidebar\n \n‚Ä¢ \nArchive the project\n \n‚Ä¢ \nDelete the project.\n \nTo access it, simply hover over the desired app/project, right click on the three dots icon near the project, and choose the needed option.           "content": "Notifications | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢ **     Using Hive Messaging & Communications Notifications \n# Notifications\n \nHow Hive provides updates on what's going on in your workspace\n Written by Erin Gouveia Updated over a year ago  \nWhether out on vacation or in a meeting, it's important to be able to easily catch up on what's happened while you were away.¬†\n\nHive notifications makes it easy to keep track of these critical changes.¬†\n\n To access your notifications, **click the bell in the upper right corner of the app.¬†\n\nIf you have something new to review, an orange dot will appear next to the bell.¬†\n \nHive notifications are divided into five categories:\n \n**Me** - Updates that are specific to you will live in the 'My notifications' tab. These are things such as new assignments, @ mentions, or direct chats.¬†\n \n‚Ä¢ \n**All **- Updates on actions you are following*\n \n‚Ä¢ \n**Mentions** - Updates on notifications where you were @ mentioned\n \n‚Ä¢ \n**Archived - **Notifications you archived\n \n‚Ä¢ \n**Pinned - **Notifications you pinned for a later use.\n \n*****You become a Follower of an action card (and therefore start receiving notifications on the card) if you:¬†\n \n‚Ä¢ \nCreate the card\n \n‚Ä¢ \nAre assigned to the card\n \n‚Ä¢ \nAre @ mentioned in the comment section\n \n‚Ä¢ \nComment on the card\n \nThe goal is to make it easier to find what you need. When you want to know about changes to work you are assigned to, check Me. If you want to check on work that you are following, then go to All.\n\nSee below for a breakdown of when a notification arrives in All, Me, Mentions, and Archived.\n\n# Reviewing your notifications\n \nWhen you see the orange dot appear on your notifications bell, click it to see what's happened in Hive.\n\n## Read and archive\n \nYou can mark a notification as read, just like you would an email, and return to it later.\n\nYou can also click each item to go to the specific action card or message it references. This way, you can use your notifications as a to-do list of items you need to take action on. \n\nOnce you're ready, you can click \"Archive\" to remove the notification from your list.\n\n## Bulk actions and unarchive\n \nHave a lot of notifications? Click \"Mark all as read\" to bulk read them. Then you can click \"Archive all\" to clear them from your list!\n\nTo go back and review an item you have already marked as read, click the \"Archived\" tab. You can select the \"mark as unread\" icon if you want to move it back to your notifications list.\n\n# Offline notifications\n \nWhen you are offline, notifications will also be pushed to your email and mobile in order for you to stay up to date with the latest changes. Your profile is moved to an 'offline' state when you exit out of the app or if you are inactive for 10 minutes.¬†\n\nTo manage your offline notification settings, go to your profile dropdown > Edit profile > Notification settings. Here you can toggle On/Off both email and mobile offline notifications.\n\nNote: this is also where you can manage banner notifications.           "url": "https://help.hive.com/en/articles/685378-notifications-preferences",
          "content": "# Notifications Preferences\n \nHow to control where and what you want to be notified about\n Written by Erin Gouveia Updated over 11 months ago \nAll notifications in Hive pop up in the bell in the upper right corner of the screen.¬†\n\nHowever, if you want to know what's going on in Hive outside the app, Hive can let you know.¬†\n\n Where can Hive send you notifications?**\n \nDesktop\n \n‚Ä¢ \nMobile\n \n‚Ä¢ \nEmail\n \n**What can you get notifications about?**\n \n‚Ä¢ \nUnread messages\n \n‚Ä¢ \nUpdates to actions you follow\n \n‚Ä¢ \n@mentions\n \n‚Ä¢ \nProofing requests\n \n‚Ä¢ \nTimesheet reminders\n \n‚Ä¢ \nUpcoming deadlines\n \n‚Ä¢ \nResource assignments\n \nHive can also send you notifications when you are away from the app.\n\nIf you are logged in and haven't interacted with the app recently, your status will change and Hive will send you email and mobile notifications. That way you can be sure that you are updated on everything your team is doing.\n\nIf you don't want to receive notifications when you away from the app, you can change those settings.\n\n**When does my status change?**\n \nYour status will change from active to away after 10 minutes of inactivity.           "content": "Hive Projects | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢ **     Using Hive Projects Hive Projects \n# Hive Projects\n \nIn 20 seconds, create a private space to collaborate within a workspace\n Written by Erin Gouveia Updated over a year ago  \nAll teams have certain information and projects that can't be visible to everyone. This could include employee salaries, private client information, or personal projects.¬†\n\nThat's why Hive has projects!\n\nEvery task created in Hive projects is completely self-contained and can only be seen by the project members. \n\nThat way you can share a workspace, but protect certain sensitive information or just make sure others aren't distracted by information irrelevant to them.\n\nHere's how:\n\n## Click the Project Navigator\n\nThis button takes you to the page where you can manage all your projects.\n\n## Click the \"+New Project\" button\n \nOnce you arrive in the Project Navigator, you can click the blue button in the upper left corner of the screen that says \"+New Project.\"\n\n## Choose how you want to create a new project\n \nChoose if this new project will be a blank project, created from a template, or created by importing a file.\n \nThen give your project a name and pick a color you want to be associated with your project. \n\n## Add team members\n \nThe team members you select for your project are the ONLY people who can see it. All the tasks in the project will be completely invisible to anyone who is not a team member.¬†\n\nSo it's really important to consider who you want to invite in the project. Each project has three options:\n \n'Everyone': Anyone now or in the future who is added to the workspace will be a member of the project. Note ** : this option is disabled once the workspace has more than 30 users. \n \n‚Ä¢ \n'Specific people': You can select others, either by team or one-by-one\n \n‚Ä¢ \n'Private to me': Just you can see this project\n\n## Select your Editing & Project Visibility Settings:\n \nYou may want to limit if others in your project can also edit project membership. If you'd like to restrict that to just you, as the project owner, then select 'Project Owner only' as shown above.\n\nIf you'd like project members to be notified, you can select the **Notify users **checkbox.\n\nIf you're going to be assigning tasks but are not quite ready to spread the word yet, Draft mode is a great option for you!**‚Äã\n\n## Select a project layout (you can change it later)\n \nThere are seven ways to view your project:\n \n‚Ä¢ \n Status view ** - actions move across the board through various stages (e.g. unstarted -> in progress -> completed)\n \n‚Ä¢ \n** Team view ** - all actions are organized in lists by the person they are assigned to\n \n‚Ä¢ \n** Calendar view ** - see actions by deadline and in the long term\n \n‚Ä¢ \n** Label view ** - actions are organized in lists by label\n \n‚Ä¢ \n** Gantt view ** - a chart that shows all your actions in a series of horizontal lines that represent the timeline they will be completed.\n \n‚Ä¢ \n** Table view ** - a list of your actions with columns organizing action and project information\n \n‚Ä¢ \n** List view ** - expanded list of all actions in your project with customizable filters\n\nIf you want a project to be visible to only you, just slide the \"Private view\" toggle on the bottom of the dropdown.\n\nFor more information on saving project Tabs, click here .\n\n## Hit create and start adding actions in your new project!\n \nIt's as easy as just typing what you want to do and press enter.¬†\n\nEvery action card in your project shows the name of the project. If you click the drop down, you can switch the action's project.\n\nIf you ever want to edit or see your project information, select \"Overview\" to view and amend project members and update key project details, such as status, custom fields, description, and attachments.¬†\n\nSelecting the \"More\" button at the top right of your screen and clicking \"Edit project\" will open up the project modal for easy updates to your project.\n\n Related Articles Hive Forms Understanding Hive's Platform Teams in Hive Project access Run a modern agency on Hive  üòû üòê üòÉ \n‚Ä¢ Sign In \n‚Ä¢ Forgot Password? \n‚Ä¢ API \n‚Ä¢ \n‚Ä¢",

          "content": "Hive Forms | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢ **     Using Hive Workflows with Forms & Automation Hive Forms \n# Hive Forms\n \nSubmit forms that automatically add pre-populated Hive actions\n Written by Erin Gouveia Updated over 5 months ago  \nIn Hive, you can create custom forms that anyone (i.e., internally or externally) can fill out in their browser. Submitted forms have the option to automatically create an action card in Hive with all the form details. ‚Äã Some great uses for Hive forms can include:\n \ncollecting orders or requests\n \n‚Ä¢ \nsubmitting bugs and other issues\n \n‚Ä¢ \ngathering structuring information from employees (e.g. contact info)\n \n‚Ä¢ \ncapturing details for a new project request\n \n‚Ä¢ \nand much more!\n\n# How to create:\n \n‚Ä¢ \nEnable \"Forms\" from \"Hive Apps\" if it's not already enabled\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSelect \"Forms\"\n \n‚Ä¢ \nClick \"Create new form\" from the Forms Library page\n\n‚Ä¢ \nAdd a title and description\n \n‚Ä¢ \nDrag and drop the fields you want to add to the form\n \nThere are multiple different question type options and dynamic fields you can add to a Hive form. \n\nBelow are example questions that can be created using a Hive form:\n\n Checkbox Group¬† \n\n Date Field \n\n *Users can choose Min Date, Max Date/Min Date and Max Date to configure what dates a user can select from the form, this setting can be found in the edit modal for the Date Field in Forms. \n\n File Upload (can support any type of file) \n\n Header \n\n Paragraph \n\n Radio Group \n\n Text Field (Single or paragraph) \n\n Text Area \n\n Ruler \n\n Multi-text \n\nDepending on which field you choose, you have the option to make it required, add help text, set a max character length, and other customizations.\n \n‚Ä¢ \n Add confirmation message**\n \nThis is the message that the person will see after they submit the form.\n\n‚Ä¢ \n**Set where you want to submit the form¬†**\n\n# **Form Statuses **\n \nTo better control form versions and updates without losing prior submission data, we have three form statuses: **Draft, Published, and Archived.**\n\n‚Ä¢ \n**Draft** - This is where you work on designing, editing, or testing a form before it's ready for use.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nOnce you've made updates to your form or created a draft of it, selecting \"**Save**\" saves the form and maintains the ** Draft ** state. This means the edits you've made will ** not ** be published.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSelecting the \"**Publish**\" button saves the changes and allows the updated form to be displayed for members in the workspace.**‚Äã ‚Äã\n \n‚Ä¢ \nAll users can see a Draft Form in the Form Library, but it can only be published by the form owner or an Admin.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIf a member of your team opens a link to a Draft Form, they will get a message indicating this form is under construction and cannot be submitted.\n\n2. Published**\n \n‚Ä¢ \nOnce your form is ready to go live, selecting \"**Publish**\" will both** save and publish **the latest version of the form.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nAll members of your team can see published forms.\n\nCurious how to switch the form from Published back to Draft?**‚Äã\n \n As an Admin or form owner, ** you might decide the form needs modifications made in the Draft status. To unpublish the form, navigate to the three dots menu at the top of the screen to Mark it as draft.\n\n3. **Archived**\n \n‚Ä¢ \nArchive/Unarchive options in the form are only available for form owner and Admins. \n \n‚Ä¢ \nIf a member of your team opens a link to the Archived Form, they will get the same message as above indicating the form is unavailable.\n\n# **Pinning your Form: Individually vs Workspace pinning****\n \nThis allows quick access to forms you use on a day-to-day basis or find yourself frequently using. \n \n If everyone in the workspace does not have the same go-to forms, you can pin a form for yourself only **in your Personal Form Library. Individually pinned forms will sit at the top of the Library and remain in the same position just for you (similar to pinning Notes and Projects).\n\nIf you prefer to pin a form ** for all workspace members, ** you can use 'shortcuts'. When a form shortcut is created, all users can access it via the 'New' dropdown in Hive.\n\n# **Determine where the submitted forms should route**\n \nOnce someone has submitted a form, the data can go to a few places.\n\n‚Ä¢ \n** Hive Action ** - Selecting the 'Create new action from form submission' option will automatically create an action card in Hive in a designated project and assign the action to the person(s) you select. It will look like this:\n \n# Creating Actions Directly Under Specific Sections\n \nTo create an action directly under a specific section in a Hive project when a form is submitted, use the Hive Workflows app. Follow these steps:\n \n‚Ä¢ \n**Set Up a Workflow**: Open the Hive Workflows app and create a new workflow.\n \n‚Ä¢ \n**Define the Trigger**: Set the trigger to activate when an action is created in your desired project via a form submission.\n \n‚Ä¢ \n**Configure the Section Update**: Adjust the workflow settings to automatically update the section of the newly created action, ensuring it is placed under the correct section in your project.\n \nThis setup allows you to organize newly created actions directly under specific project sections, improving project structure and management.\n\n** 1.1. Hive Sub-Action ** - Selecting the 'Create new action from submission' option and choosing a parent action card will automatically create a sub-action card under the parent action card.\n\nThe sub-action will look like this:\n\n1.2.** Create another new action from form submission ** - Selecting the \"Create another new action from form submission\" option will create a separate action in another project/assigned to another user/ etc.**‚Äã Another optional but great way is to use the \"Only create this action IF\" condition and set specific criteria for your form submissions. ‚Äã\n\n 2. Project ** - Selecting the 'Create new project submission' option will automatically create a new project each time the form is submitted. On the edit page of each question, you can designate the question selections to be mapped to the new project description and/or project custom fields areas.\n\n** 2.1. Update an existing project from the form submission ** - Selecting this option will make the submission completely update the existing project according to the information entered in the request. On the edit page of each question, you can designate the question selections to be mapped to the exsiting project description and/or project custom fields areas.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nNote: Form submissions cannot update the description of an existing action card. Instead, new action cards are generated. Use custom field mappings for better data integration.\n\n For additional settings, open the **\"Settings panel\"** at the bottom of the page. \n \n# Common Use Cases and Best Practices\n \n‚Ä¢ \n**Project Organizing**: Use workflows to automatically place tasks in appropriate sections for better team visibility.\n \n‚Ä¢ \n**Data Structuring**: Leverage custom field mapping to capture key form details precisely where needed in your templates.\n \n‚Ä¢ \n**Troubleshooting**: Ensure your workflows are correctly triggered by testing with sample form submissions and verifying task placement.\n \nBy following these guidelines, you can maximize the utility of Hive Forms and streamline your project setups.\n\n** Email submitter ** - Selecting the 'Each time a form is submitted, send a copy to the form submitter' option will send an email with all of the entered information to the person who filled out the form.\n\n**‚Äã Require Hive sign-in **- Selecting the 'Require sign-in for form submissions' option will require those submitting the form to sign into Hive in order to submit the form.\n\n** Permission Settings ** - Selecting the 'Only admins and form creator can edit' option restricts editing to the form creator and admins.\n\n# **Preview a form**\n \nThe new Form Builder allows users to preview what Forms will look like when sent externally. At the top of the page, select \"Preview\" to view the Form.\n\nYou can also customize preview settings to ensure correct formatting from different devices (iPhone, Desktop, etc.). Click the computer icon in the top right corner and a list of devices will populate.\n\n# **Sharing the form Externally**\n \nEach form comes with a link that you can share or post on a website.¬†\n\nTo access the link, on the Forms Library page click the 'Copy URL' button to save it to your clipboard where you can then post it where you would like.\n\nWhen a person clicks on the form, they will be taken to a web page that looks something like this.\n\nThere they can fill out and submit their information.\n\nThe \"Form\" feature is definitely an awesome way to get things done!**‚Äã ‚Äã\n \n# Internal vs. External form title\n \nTeams often have an internal naming convention for their forms, making it easier for internal teammates to identify and use them, but want to add a clear title for external people filling out the form. So, let's dive into the details! ‚Äã To bridge this communication gap, you can add an External title right under the Internal one. The external title will be visible for form submitters.\n\n# Rich text in the form fields\n \nTo make it easier to highlight important or significant information, we have added the ability to format text in forms by using hotkeys. With this feature, you can now bold, italicize, and underline text within any text field answers. The formatting you apply in the forms will also carry over to Hive to the completed card/project.\n\nHere is a step-by-step guide on how to use:\n \n‚Ä¢ \nOpen a form\n \n‚Ä¢ \nAdd text area / single input / multi-text field\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSave the form\n \n‚Ä¢ \nOpen it to submit\n \n‚Ä¢ \nType some text\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSelect it and hit Ctrl/Command + B/I/U keys.\n\n# Automatically save form drafts\n \nNow user's entries in the form will no longer disappear even if you leave the form! Here is some information on how the form's draft works!\n \n‚Ä¢ \nAny fields filled out in a form are saved automatically when you close the form.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nWhen you re-open the form in the same browser on the same device, the answers you had previously filled out will still be there.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nAttachments will not ** be saved, so if you re-enter the form, the attachment will need to be uploaded again.\n \n# Duplicating Form Questions\n \nUsers will be able to duplicate the question in the form by clicking on the Duplicate button in the Form Editor!\n \n‚Ä¢ \nAny Logic that was placed in the question will carry over.\n\n# Enable/disable holidays & weekends\n \nIf you'd like to allow your users to select weekends / holidays when submitting the form or instead, limit them from doing so, you'll use the following guidance:\n \n‚Ä¢ \nWhen editing the form, click on your Date question > Data section > Ensure the setting to \"Include holidays\"/ \"Include weekends\" is checked.\n\n‚Ä¢ \n\na) If your form is creating an action card in a specific project, go to your project settings and ensure the option to \"Allow actions to be assigned on weekends\" is checked.\n \n Note: If your form is creating a project using a project template, you'll check this setting in your project template settings. \n\nb) If your form is creating an action without a project or an entirely new project, you'll go to your Workspace Settings > Project default settings > check the option to \"Allow actions to be assigned on weekends\".\n\n# **Custom Logo for each form**\n \nTo upload a custom logo for each form, use the External Logo option in the General settings. This feature will enable each form to display a distinct logo, providing a personalized visual representation for each user interaction.\n\n# **Viewing & Downloading Form Submissions**\n \nYou can access the Form Submissions page by visiting the main Forms Library and clicking on the Form Stats.**‚Äã\n\nThis view allows you to see:\n \n‚Ä¢ \nLink to the submission\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSubmission title\n \n‚Ä¢ \nDate of the submission\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSubmitted By\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSubmission Type (Action/Project)\n \n‚Ä¢ \nStatus (Action/Project status)\n \n‚Ä¢ \nOther columns for all questions within the form and their recorded responses.\n \nFiltering and sorting options for columns are coming soon!\n\nUsers can also download the form submissions from the Submissions page.\n \n *Note - If the Form has a special character, the download will fail. Please do not include any special characters in the form title when exporting. \n\nThe export will include these columns in the CSV file:\n \n Submission**\n \n**Submitted At**\n \n**Submitted By**\n \n**Type**\n \n**Status**\n \nThis will be the title of the submission\n \nThis will show the date and time of when the form was submitted\n \nThis will show the name of the user who submitted the form\n \nThis will show what was created from the form submission\n \nThis will display the Status of the action card or project created from the submission.\n \n**+ Other columns for all questions within the form and their recorded responses.**\n\n# **Track submission progress**\n \nYou can also easily track the progress of your form submissions in real time! Forget the ‚ÄúJust checking in‚Äù emails ‚Äî now the submission status & all details are visible instantly on the My Submissions page.\n\nTo enable this option for your users, go to the Form Editor and check the \"Allow submitters to track the form progress\" setting within the Submission Settings. \n\nUsers will be able to track progress after submission via this URL ( https://forms.hive.com/my-submissions ) or by clicking the 'View my Submissions' button right after the submission.\n\nSubmitters can do the following via this link:\n \n‚Ä¢ \nview all your submissions across all forms and workspaces\n \n‚Ä¢ \nclick on the submission to briefly view more details, add a comment, and mention action followers.\n\nTo comment on the submission or @mention another user, you'll click on your submission on the 'My submissions' page and use the Comment section at the bottom.\n\n Related Articles Import tasks into Hive Hive for Slack Dynamic Fields in Hive Forms Run a modern agency on Hive Form Submissions Page  üòû üòê üòÉ \n‚Ä¢ Sign In \n‚Ä¢ Forgot Password? \n‚Ä¢ API \n‚Ä¢ \n‚Ä¢",

          "content": "Dynamic Fields in Hive Forms | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢     Using Hive Workflows with Forms & Automation Dynamic Fields in Hive Forms \n# Dynamic Fields in Hive Forms\n \nFurther customize a form using dynamic fields\n Written by Michaela Rollings Updated over 9 months ago  \nJust getting started with forms? Review the article here to get you caught up.¬†\n\nHive forms has become even more powerful with the introduction of dynamic fields.\n\n# Dynamic Users\n \nDynamic users can automatically assign a member of your team to the action card that is created when a form is submitted. Once a form is submitted, that user is notified that they have been assigned a new action. When editing the field, be sure to click \"Map to action assignee\" to automatically assign the user to the card. \n\nOnly members of the project in which the form is being directed to will be available in the user dropdown list. For example, if I have a form being directed to a shared project only available to myself and another coworker, we are the only two users who will be available for selection in the dropdown. This is to protect project membership and assignment as you are only able to be assigned actions within projects that you are a member of.¬†\n\n# Dynamic Projects\n \nDynamic Project Question allows you to map the action card to a selected project or automatically link the action card to a project.\n\nIf the ‚ÄúMap to project‚Äù option is selected, the submission will create the action card in the selected project within the Dynamic Project Question.\n\nIf the ‚ÄúMap to linked projects‚Äù option is selected, the submission will create the action card in the project selected at the bottom of the form, but the action card will be linked to the chosen project.\n\n *Note - You must make sure the Form owner is part of the project you want to choose since the project you're searching for won't be in the dropdown if the Form owner is not part of the project. \n\n# Dynamic Labels\n \nWith dynamic labels, the form submitter can select which label their form relates to. The action is then auto-labeled for the team that receives the request. When editing the field, select \"Map to label\". Then in the 'Available labels' drop-down, choose the labels that will be available for selection in this form.\n\nOnce complete, the user will be able to choose their assignee, project, and label(s) when submitting a form, and those fields will map directly back to Hive.¬†\n\n# Dynamic Custom Fields\n \nYou can also have dynamic custom fields in your form. You can choose between project and action custom fields. \n\nIf you go for action custom fields, don't forget to select 'Map it to action custom field' so that the response automatically fills in the custom field in the resulting action card.\n\n# Dynamic Priorities\n \nFinally, you may select the Dynamic Priorities question type, to display a drop-down list of the action card priorities in the workspace to the form submitter.           "content": "What is Hive Automate? | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢    Hive Automate Getting Started What is Hive Automate? \n# What is Hive Automate?\n Written by Donnell Tanadi Updated over 3 years ago \nHive Automate is a powerful new feature that allows you to take control over the specific integration and automation needs of your team within Hive.           "content": "Starting & Stopping Recipes | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢ **     Hive Automate Recipe Management Starting & Stopping Recipes \n# Starting & Stopping Recipes\n Written by Michaela Rollings Updated over 3 years ago  \nYou can work with recipes in various ways:\n \ntest a recipe to run a single trigger event through the recipe logic\n \n‚Ä¢ \nstart a recipe to have it pick up trigger events\n \n‚Ä¢ \nstop a recipe to have it stop processing new trigger events\n \n‚Ä¢ \nuse skip step to build and test your recipes incrementally\n \nDuring recipe development, we recommend building and testing in small chunks. To enter test mode, click Test jobs** or the **Test** button in the top right corner of the Recipe editor.\n\n# **Starting Recipes**\n \nStarting a recipe will cause it to pick up trigger events and process them through the recipe. When a recipe is started, it becomes **active**.\n\nStarting a recipe with a real-time trigger (like those in the Hive connector) will result in the recipe immediately listening for the specified events, with the specified trigger conditions. It will keep fetching events until the recipe is stopped.\n\nWhen a recipe with trigger time intervals is first started, it will fetch trigger events from the 'when first started, this recipe should pick up events from' configuration. Subsequently, it will continuously process these events. If you had defined the **Since/From** date during testing previously, this date cannot be changed again for this recipe\n \n## \n\n# **Stopping Recipes**\n \nStopping a recipe makes it **inactive**. It will stop picking up trigger events. Recipes have to be stopped to make changes to the recipe, or to rename the recipe.\n\nReal-time triggers powered by webhooks (like those in the Hive connector) will trigger events that occur during the time that the recipe is running. If the recipe was stopped triggers will not be picked up by the recipe during the time of inactivity.\n\nRecipes with trigger intervals will continue where they have left off when a recipe is restarted from a stopped state. For example, if it was stopped on Monday, and started again from Thursday, the recipe will fetch all trigger events since Monday and process them.\n\n ‚Äã\n Related Articles What is Hive Automate?           "title": "Formulas & Lists (Automate)",
          "url": "https://help.hive.com/en/articles/6483151-formulas-lists",
          "content": "# Formulas: Lists\n Written by Michaela Rollings Updated over 3 years ago  \nIn addition to the basic data types (for example, string and integer), you may encounter more complex data structures that contain information about multiple items or multiple pieces of information about a single item. You may encounter Lists, Hashes, or Lists of Hashes. Formulas in Hive Automate are whitelisted Ruby methods, and therefore not all Ruby methods are supported.\n\nYou can refer to the syntax and sample uses of these commands by clicking the links below: \n \n Lists (arrays) \n \n Hashes \n \n Lists of hashes \n \n Example list of hashes \n \n first \n \n last \n \n index \n \n where \n \n except \n \n pluck \n \n format_map \n \n join \n \n smart_join \n \n reverse \n \n sum \n \n uniq \n \n flatten \n \n length \n \n max \n \n min \n \n compact \n \n blank? \n \n include? \n \n present? \n \n presence \n \n to_csv \n \n to_json \n \n to_xml \n \n from_xml \n \n encode_www_form \n \n to_param \n \n keys \n\n# Lists (arrays)**\n \nArrays are ordered, integer-indexed collections of any object. List indexing starts at 0. Lists and arrays refer to the same data structure.\n \nIn the example below, a list of integers is expressed as:\n \nnumber_list = [100, 101, 102, 103, 104] As lists are ordered, we can use the following formula to get the values. Hive Automate only supports retrieving up to the fifth item using this syntax.\n \n**Formula**\n \n**Result**\n \nnumber_list.first\n \n100\n \nnumber_list.second\n \n101\n \nnumber_list.third\n \n102\n \nnumber_list.fourth\n \n103\n \nnumber_list.fifth\n \n104\n \nnumber_list.last\n \n104\n \nWe can also use indexes to get corresponding values. Remember, indexes start at 0:\n \n**Formula**\n \n**Result**\n \nnumber_list[0]\n \n100\n \nnumber_list[1]\n \n101\n \nnumber_list[2]\n \n102\n \nnumber_list[3]\n \n103\n \nLists in Ruby supports negative indexes.\n \n**Formula**\n \n**Result**\n \nnumber_list[-1]\n \n104\n \nnumber_list[-2]\n \n103\n \nnumber_list[-3]\n \n102\n \nnumber_list[-4]\n \n101\n \nLists also support ranges as indexes. This returns another list, instead of returning only a value.\n \n**Formula**\n \n**Result**\n \nnumber_list[0..2]\n \n[100, 101, 102]\n \nnumber_list[-3..-1]\n \n[102, 103, 104]\n \nnumber_list[0..-2]\n \n[100, 101, 102, 103]\n\n# **Hashes**\n \nA hash is a dictionary-like collection of unique keys and their values. They are similar to Lists, but where a List uses integers as its index, a Hash allows you to use any object type. Hashes enumerate their values in the order that the corresponding keys were inserted.\n \nLet's take the example of a hash with 2 values, with 'Acme widgets' and 10 as the values of item_name and item_quantity respectively.\n\nline_item = { 'item_name' => 'Acme widgets', 'item_qty' => 10 } **Formula**\n \n**Result**\n \nline_item[\"item_name\"]\n \n\"Acme widgets\"\n \nline_item[\"item_qty\"]\n \n10\n\n# **Lists of hashes**\n \nHere is an example of an invoice which has multiple line items. It is represented as a list of hashes.\n \nline_items = [ { 'item_no': 1, 'item_name' => 'Acme widgets', 'item_qty' => 10 }, { 'item_no': 2, 'item_name' => 'RR bearings', 'item_qty' => 99 }, { 'item_no': 3, 'item_name' => 'Coyote tyres', 'item_qty' => 7 } ] \n \n# \n \n# **Example list of hashes**\n \nThe following is an example of a list of hashes called **Contacts**.\n \nThis is the Contacts list in a table form:\n \n**name**\n \n**email**\n \n**state**\n \n**company**\n \n**company_rev**\n \nJoe\n \n joe@abc.com \n \nCA\n \nABC\n \n1000\n \nJill\n \n jill@nbc.com \n \nMA\n \nNBC\n \n1000\n \nJoan\n \n joan@nbc.com \n \nMA\n \nNBC\n \n10000\n \nJack\n \n jack@hbo.com \n \nCA\n \nHBO\n \n30000\n \nThis is the Contacts list in a list of hashes form.\n \n[ **{ 'name' => 'Joe', 'email' => 'joe@abc.com', 'state' => 'CA', 'company' => 'ABC', 'company_rev' => 1000, 'description' => { 'summary' => 'First time buyer', 'estimated_value' => 300 } }, { 'name' => 'Jill', 'email' => 'jill@nbc.com', 'state' => 'MA', 'company' => 'NBC', 'company_rev' => 1000, 'description' => { 'summary' => 'Referral', 'estimated_value' => 500 } }, { 'name' => 'Joan', 'email' => 'joan@nbc.com', 'state' => 'MA', 'company' => 'NBC', 'company_rev' => 10000, 'description' => { 'summary' => 'Recurring customer', 'estimated_value' => 900 } }, { 'name' => 'Jack', 'email' => 'jack@hbo.com', 'state' => 'CA', 'company' => 'HBO', 'company_rev' => 30000, 'description' => { 'summary' => 'Recurring customer', 'estimated_value' => 1000 } } ] \n\n# first**\n \nThis formula returns the first item in a list.\n \nIt can also be used to return the first n items in a list. In this case, the output will be formatted as a list.\n\n## Syntax\n \nList.first(number)\n \nList - An input list.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nnumber - (optional) The number of items to retrieve from the list. If not specified, the formula will return only one item.\n \n## Sample usage\n \n**Formula**\n \n**Result**\n \n[\"One\",\"Two\",\"Three\",\"Four\",\"Five\"].first()\n \n\"One\"\n \n[\"One\",\"Two\",\"Three\",\"Four\",\"Five\"].first(2)\n \n[\"One\",\"Two\"]\n \n[1,2,3,4,5].first()\n \n1\n \n[1,2,3,4,5].first(3)\n \n[1,2,3]\n \n## How it works\n \nThis formula returns the first n items from a list. If n is greater than one, the output is formatted as a list.\n\n# **last**\n \nThis formula returns the last item in a list.\n \nIt can also be used to return the last n items in a list. In this case, the output will be formatted as a list.\n\n## Syntax\n \nList.last(number)\n \n‚Ä¢ \nList - An input list.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nnumber - (optional) The number of items to retrieve from the list. If not specified, the formula will return only one item.\n \n## Sample usage\n \n**Formula**\n \n**Result**\n \n[\"One\",\"Two\",\"Three\",\"Four\",\"Five\"].last()\n \n\"Five\"\n \n[\"One\",\"Two\",\"Three\",\"Four\",\"Five\"].last(2)\n \n[\"Four\",\"Five\"]\n \n[1,2,3,4,5].last()\n \n5\n \n[1,2,3,4,5].last(3)\n \n[3,4,5]\n \n## How it works\n \nThis formula returns the last n items from a list. If n is greater than one, the output is formatted as a list.\n\n# **index**\n \nReturns the index of the first item matching the given value. Returns nil if no matching items are found.\n\n## Syntax\n \nInput.index(value)\n \n‚Ä¢ \nInput - An input list.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nvalue - The value to search for in the list.\n \n## Sample usage\n \n**Formula**\n \n**Result**\n \n[4, 5, 6, 7].index(6)\n \n2\n \n[4, 5, 6, 7].index(8)\n \nnil\n\n# **where**\n \nRetrieves only the rows (hashes) which satisfy the specified WHERE condition. This formula accepts a single argument in the form of a hash with one or more key-value pairs.\n \nThe default operand for the condition is **equal to** ( == ). This formula also supports the following operands. Operands should be added to the end of key separated by a space.\n \n**Name**\n \n**Notation**\n \n**Example**\n \nEqual to (default)\n \n==\n \nleads.where('state': 'CA')\n \nMore than\n \n>\n \nleads.where('company_revenue >\": 10000)\n \nMore than or equal to\n \n>=\n \nleads.where('company_revenue >=\": 10000)\n \nLess than\n \n<\n \nleads.where('company_revenue <\": 10000)\n \nLess than or equal to\n \n<=\n \nleads.where('company_revenue <=\": 10000)\n \nNot equal to\n \n!=\n \nleads.where('state !=': 'CA')\n \n**Example of a single where condition**\n \n contacts.where('state': 'CA') returns the following rows:\n \n**name**\n \n**email**\n \n**state**\n \n**company**\n \n**company_rev**\n \nJoe\n \n joe@abc.om \n \nCA\n \nABC\n \n1000\n \nJack\n \n jack@hbo.com \n \nCA\n \nHBO\n \n30000\n \nThese rows will be expressed as a list of hashes:\n \n[ **{ 'name' => 'Joe', 'email' => 'joe@abc.com', 'state' => 'CA', 'company' => 'ABC', 'company_rev' => 1000 }, { 'name' => 'Jack', 'email' => 'jack@hbo.com', 'state' => 'CA', 'company' => 'HBO', 'company_rev' => 30000 } ] \n \n Example of a compound where formula**\n \nA compound WHERE formula will retrieve only the rows that matches all the conditions.\n \n contacts.where('state': 'CA', 'company_revenue >=\": 10000) \n \nwill returns the following rows:\n \n**name**\n \n**email**\n \n**state**\n \n**company**\n \n**company_rev**\n \nJack\n \n jack@hbo.com \n \nCA\n \nHBO\n \n30000\n \nThese rows will be expressed as a list of hashes:\n \n[ **{ 'name' => 'Jack', 'email' => 'jack@hbo.com', 'state' => 'CA', 'company' => 'HBO', 'company_rev' => 30000 } ] \n \n Example of multiple matches**\n \nYou can filter out records based on a particular field against more than 1 value. This is done by passing an array value in the WHERE condition.\n \n contacts.where('company': ['ABC','HBO']) \n \nThis WHERE condition will return rows where the company is either **ABC** or **HBO**:\n \n**name**\n \n**email**\n \n**state**\n \n**company**\n \n**company_rev**\n \nJoe\n \n joe@abc.om \n \nCA\n \nABC\n \n1000\n \nJack\n \n jack@hbo.com \n \nCA\n \nHBO\n \n30000\n \nThese rows will be returned as a list of hashes.\n \n[ **{ 'name' => 'Joe', 'email' => 'joe@abc.com', 'state' => 'CA', 'company' => 'ABC', 'company_rev' => 1000 }, { 'name' => 'Jack', 'email' => 'jack@hbo.com', 'state' => 'CA', 'company' => 'HBO', 'company_rev' => 30000 } ] \n \n Example where condition with pattern matching**\n \nYou can also filter out records using regex. This is done by passing a regex instead of a string.\n \n contacts.where('name': /^Jo/) \n \nThis WHERE condition will return rows where the name starts with **Jo**:\n \n**name**\n \n**email**\n \n**state**\n \n**company**\n \n**company_rev**\n \nJoe\n \n joe@abc.om \n \nCA\n \nABC\n \n1000\n \nJoan\n \n joan@nbc.com \n \nMA\n \nNBC\n \n10000\n \nThese rows will be expressed as a list of hashes:\n \n[ **{ 'name' => 'Joe', 'email' => 'joe@abc.com', 'state' => 'CA', 'company' => 'ABC', 'company_rev' => 1000 }, { 'name' => 'Joan', 'email' => 'joan@nbc.com', 'state' => 'MA', 'company' => 'NBC', 'company_rev' => 10000 } ] \n \n Example where condition with pattern matching (using datapills)**\n \nYou may use data pills within a regex pattern to dynamically change the string that you are matching. => { a: true, b: false } hash.except(:a, :b) # => { c: nil } hash # => { a: true, b: false, c: nil } \n\n# pluck**\n \n Retrieves only the columns which have been specified.\n\n## Sample usage\n\n**Example of a single column dataput**\n \n contacts.pluck(\"email\") returns\n \n**email**\n \n joe@abc.com \n \n jill@nbc.com \n \n joan@nbc.com \n \n jack@hbo.com \n \nIf a single column, results will be returned as an array:\n \n[\"joe@abc.com\", \"jill@nbc.com\", \"joan@nbc.com\", \"jack@hbo.com\"] \n \n**Example of a multiple column dataset**\n \n contacts.where(\"state ==\": \"CA\").pluck(\"email\", \"company\") returns\n \n**email**\n \n**company**\n \n joe@abc.com \n \nABC\n \n jill@nbc.com \n \nNBC\n \n joan@nbc.com \n \nNBC\n \n jack@hbo.com \n \nHBO\n \nResults are returned as a list of a list:\n \n[[\"joe@abc.com\", \"ABC\"], [\"jill@nbc.com\", \"NBC\"], [\"joan@nbc.com\", \"NBC\"], [\"jack@hbo.com\", \"HBO\"]] \n \n**Example of retrieving nested fields**\n \nThis method can be used to extract nested fields. Use the [<1st-level field>,<2nd-level field>...] format to define which fields to retrieve.\n \n contacts.pluck(\"email\", [\"description\", \"summary\"]) returns\n \n**email**\n \n**summary**\n \n joe@abc.com \n \nFirst time buyer\n \n jill@nbc.com \n \nReferral\n \n joan@nbc.com \n \nRecurring customer\n \n jack@hbo.com \n \nRecurring customer\n \nResults are returned as a list of lists:\n \n[ [\"joe@abc.com\", \"First time buyer\"], [\"jill@nbc.com\", \"Referral\"], [\"joan@nbc.com\", \"Recurring customer\"], [\"jack@hbo.com\", \"Recurring customer\"] ] \n\n# **format_map**\n \nCreate an array of strings by formatting each row of given array of hashes.
