          "content": "Recipe Build: Form Submission - Update Action Based on Label | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢ **     Hive Automate Use Cases Recipe Build: Form Submission - Update Action Based on Label \n# Recipe Build: Form Submission - Update Action Based on Label\n Written by Michaela Rollings Updated over 3 years ago  \nThis guide will walk you through how to build the following community library recipe from scratch:\n\nIf you would like to start with the completed recipe, you can refer to this article for instructions on how to copy a recipe from the community library: Using a Recipe from the Hive Automate Library \n\n Build it Yourself:**\n\nInstructions to build a recipe that listens for a submission from a specific form, reads the label on the action card created, and automatically updates the action according to your needs. This example routes the card to the correct project, and will assign the card to the correct person.\n\n## Create Recipe:\n\nIn Hive go to Apps:\n\nMake sure Hive Automate is enabled for your workspace. Then click Open. \n \n *Note: If you are turning this on for the first time and don‚Äôt have the Add-on yet, you will be given a two week trial of this feature and given 500 automation tasks to use during the trial. \n\nGo to My Recipes\n\nClick Create in the top right corner and select Recipe\n\nSet up your recipe by giving it a Name, and picking a location for the recipe to save in your Hive Automate folder structure. For this recipe the starting point we want is: Trigger from an app. Click Start Building.\n\n## Trigger:\n\nWhen a Hive Form is submitted it generally does one of two things. It either creates an action, or a project in Hive. The creation of that action or project is what we want our recipe to listen to. Click on the empty Trigger step:\n\n## **App:**\n \nA new panel will open on the right side of your screen asking you to choose an app. Search for Hive and select the Hive connector:\n\n## **Connection:**\n \nIt will then ask you to select your connection for the selected app. Choose the connection you want to use:\n\nIf you don‚Äôt have a Hive connection setup you can refer to the following article: Setting up your Hive connection \n\n## **Setup:**\n \nFor this guide we will focus on the trigger event New Action. If our form is set up to create a new action card then all of the information mapped from the form is added to the card on creation. That means we can use all of that information to create automations in Hive Automate.\n\nHere in the setup we have a decision to make. How do we want the recipe to know which new cards in our workspace should be affected by this recipe? There are many ways to do this but we recommend the following two options as they are the easiest to set up.\n\n**Option 1: New actions in specific project**\n\nIn the setup of the trigger you can simply pick the specific project you would like this recipe to listen to. This configuration above will tell the recipe that it should listen for all new action cards created in the project selected in that drop down menu.\n\n**Option 2: New actions in any project**\n\nThe second option would be to set up a trigger condition based on some attribute of the new action card instead of a specific project. In the configuration of your form there is the ability to map the Form Name to the title of the submitted card. If you have selected that option you can have the trigger listen for if the title of the new action contains a specific string. You would configure the Value above to match the name of your Hive Form.\n\nYou could of course do a combination of both options listed above, so that you only listen for actions in a specific project, that also have a specific form name in the title. You can add conditions as well if you would like to narrow the trigger down further for more advanced requirements.\n\nLast step here is we want to add the following conditional:\n\nThis conditional just ensures that we are only listening to parent action cards. If you are applying a template in the form that includes subactions it would cause the recipe to run when it saw all those new subactions created as well. \n\n## Actions:\n \nNow that the trigger is configured to listen for a specific event, we need to tell the recipe what actions in the workflow we want to happen. Click the + button under the word Actions and let's take a look at our options for creating actions:\n\nHere we have a few options of what we can do with our workflow. The first four listed are the most commonly used:\n \nAction in an app: Take a step to do something in one of the connectors.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIF condition: Add a section to the recipe that only will occur if the condition is satisfied.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIF/ELSE condition: Add two sections to the recipe where only the top section will occur if the condition is satisfied, and only the bottom if the condition is not satisfied.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nRepeat action: Add a section to the recipe that will loop through a list of items.\n\n## **IF Condition:**\n\nThe workflow we are trying to implement does require that we take another Action in an app, but we don‚Äôt know what action to take yet. Let's start with the IF condition, to make sure we change the right thing, on the right Hive action card. Click IF condition.\n\nYour recipe will now have 2 new action steps. The parent step is for setting up the conditional, and the child step is blank for you to choose what to do inside the IF conditional. We can check for all kinds of attributes that the new action card has. Some ideas would be: Title, description, due-date, assignee, created by, custom fields, or labels. \n\nFor this guide we are going to look at labels. Label data on an action card is given as a list of Label IDs. We can use this list to check if it contains a specific Label ID. Essentially saying if the new action card has a specific label on it, then the IF condition is true:\n\n## **Hive - Update Action:**\n\nThis step in the recipe is nested inside the IF condition from above so that it will only run if the condition was true. We are going to go ahead and click action step 3 and select Hive as our connector again. Then select Update record:\n\nOnce the action is selected you will be brought to the setup tab. The two mandatory fields here are the type of Object, and then the ID for that object. For this workflow we want to update the Hive action card that triggered the recipe, so we pick Action as our object, and then pass the data pill ID from step 1 into the Action ID we want to edit:\n\nNow the recipe knows what record to update inside the IF condition. From here you can select any changes to that Hive action card that you would like. This is essentially where you are creating the mapping in the recipe. For the specific label, what changes are you looking to automatically apply? The most common fields to change would be the Assignee or the Project you want this action card to go to. Simply pick the values from the following drop downs that you would like. If you want to see a full list of fields available to edit you can click on the optional fields button at the bottom:\n\nCongratulations! You now have one mapping completely set up. How do we go about configuring other mappings? Hive Automate has a copy and paste feature that can make the subsequent mappings go much faster:\n\nSimply hover your mouse to the right of the Action step you wish to copy. Click the three horizontal dots, and click Copy. If you copy a conditional bucket it will automatically copy everything inside it as well.\n\nOnce copied you can then paste the selection. Hover your mouse around the area of your recipe where you want to paste the copied step(s):\n\nClick the paste button shown above and a copy of the IF section will appear. From here all you need to do is change the Label ID inside the condition step, and change the update action in Hive step to map the correct Assignee, Project, or any other fields you might have set up. You can continue the copy/paste process until all of the logic you want is complete.\n\nWe always recommend testing your recipes before starting them by hitting the Test button in the top right corner. This will turn the recipe on for one submission to test functionality. Simply hit the test button and submit a form to make sure it functions as you intended.\n\nOnce you are finished remember to Save your recipe and hit Exit. Hive Mail is an available app listed here. Toggle it on, sign in to your email account, authorize the connection, and you'll be all set!\n\nYou can now access your Hive Mail from the same left-hand navigation bar.\n\n## **What can I do with Hive Mail?**\n \n### **Easily create follow up actions**\n \nNever miss a follow up again! You (or Buzz ) can easily turn your email into an action card in Hive. Actions you create from an email will be private and assigned to you by default, and the email thread will live in the action card.\n\nTo create an action from an email, click into the email from your Hive Mail inbox, then you can either click the checkmark icon above the message:\n\nOr let Buzz do this for you: \n\nYou‚Äôll then be able to access the newly created card from the Home page. \n\n From follow-ups to drafts, Buzz gets it done! \n \n‚Ä¢ \n### **Link emails to existing actions**\n \nReceive an email that‚Äôs relevant to something you‚Äôre already working on?           "content": "Formula Custom Fields | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢ **     Using Hive Custom Fields Formula Custom Fields \n# Formula Custom Fields\n \nDynamically calculate custom fields\n A Written by Alexander Heldring Updated over 3 years ago  \nFormula custom fields allow you to create relationships between custom fields using simple or advanced formulas. \n\nFor example, if you have two existing custom fields ('Cost per person' and 'Number of people') you could create a formula custom field ('Total cost') to multiply their values. \n\nFormula custom fields are available for both project and action custom fields. To create a new formula, create a new custom field and choose the field type 'Formula'.\n\nPlease see here for a full list of supported formulas . \n\n# Mathematical Functions\n \n## Custom field syntax**\n \nFormula custom fields take the following structure:\n\n**field(\"[custom field 1]\") (operator) field(\"[custom field 2]\")**\n\nIn the example above, you would define 'Total cost' by writing the following phrase in the formula field: \n\n**field(\"Number of people\") * field(\"Cost per person\")**\n\nYou could change the formula by switching out the operator (*, -, +) or by switching the custom fields. \n\n# Date and Time Functions\n \nBelow is a table of basic date and time functions. \n \n**Syntax**\n \n**Example**\n \n**Expected Output**\n \nDAY(date)\n \nDAY('2/14/22')\n \n14\n \nMONTH(date)\n \nMONTH('2/14/22')\n \n2\n \nYEAR(date)\n \nYEAR('2/14/22')\n \n2022\n \nNOW()\n \nNOW()\n \nCurrent date/time\n \nYou can also reference 'Date' custom fields when creating new formulas. \n\nFor example, you had a custom field type = date (Kickoff Date) you could create a field which calculated the time elapsed since kickoff.           "content": "Optimize Your Project Templates | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢ **     Using Hive Projects Optimize Your Project Templates \n# Optimize Your Project Templates\n Written by Andrew Naisawald Updated over 4 months ago  \nWant to make sure that your Project Templates are optimized and ready for the most efficient use?\n\nRefer to the below checklist to make sure that your Project Templates contain all of the following components:\n\n## 1. Ensure your Project Template has a Project Start/Due Date**\n \nCheck that your template has a project start and/or due date. This acts as a link between your project template and any new projects created from this template to ensure that action durations and dependencies transfer over to the new project properly.\n\n**Pro-tip**: Ensure your **new** project also has a project start and/or due date at creation. If your template has a project start/due date, then when creating a new project from the template the project start/due date will automatically be populated for the new project.\n\n## **2. Assign actions to Placeholders**\n \nAssign the actions in your template to Placeholders . Using Placeholders in your template will allow for efficient updates to the actual resources that will be working on those actions in your project. \n\nBefore you can assign actions to Placeholders, check the Template Project Settings page to make sure Placeholders have been added to the Template. Once added to the Template, then Placeholders can be assigned to actions.\n\n## **3. Add durations and dependencies to your actions**\n \nWhile not required, ensuring that the action cards in the Project Template have relative due dates, durations, and dependencies is a best practice for optimizing Project Templates. \n\nWhile you may not know the exact duration for every action in your project, it is still recommended to add approximate start and end dates for each action. That way when applying the template, each action has a starting point to work from when shaping the project plan for the new project.\n\n## **4. Manage Labels and Apply them to Necessary Action Cards**\n \n Labels are a great way to manage key initiatives or categorize certain actions for designated teams. \n\nProject Templates can be pre-set to not only limit which labels are available in the project, but also to have labels pre-applied on action cards. That way when the template is applied for a new project, the action cards in the project come pre-set with their applicable labels helping to maintain project consistency and completeness.\n\n## 5. Grant access to the Project Template to Hive Teams\n \nIn addition to making sure members of a Hive Team have access to a template, members of the Project Template are listed by default in the Project Membership section when new projects are created using the template.\n\nAdditionally, inviting Teams rather than individuals to templates helps to ensure template membership is kept up to date as team membership changes. New members added to a Hive Team will automatically be granted access to templates and projects where the Hive Team is a member.\n\n## **6. Review your Project Settings**\n \nWhen a project template is used to create a new project, the template's project setting will apply as the default settings for the new project. Therefore, it is important to check that the project and auto-scheduling settings on the project template are appropriate.\n\nIn the project Permission settings, you can define who can edit, apply, and access\n \nthe project template.\n\nPro-tip: In your Workspace Settings, you can also select the project template you'd like to be automatically applied by default each time a new project is created.\n\nChecking that your Project Templates have the above items will set them up for success!\n\n Related Articles Action templates Project templates Adding placeholder resources to projects Run a modern agency on Hive New This Week in Hive: August 2021  üòû üòê üòÉ Sign In \n‚Ä¢ Forgot Password? \n‚Ä¢ API \n‚Ä¢ \n‚Ä¢",

Write access enabled so that users can leverage OneDrive file picker upload capabilities to add new files to OneDrive through the picker before attaching into Hive.\n \n### Hive Apps - Calendar (Office 365)\n \nThe \"Calendar\" Hive App allows for seamless integration of your calendar into Hive so that you can easily view a pop-out calendar view from inside of Hive to easily view your schedule, respond/update calendar events, get meeting reminders, open video conferencing, schedule work blocks for Actions, and integrate meeting notes for calendar events before/during/after your meetings.\n\nThe scope(s) required for the integration to function are listed below:\n \n**Scope**\n \n**Permission**\n \n**How it's used by Hive**\n \nCalendars.ReadWrite.Shared\n \nHave full access to user calendars\n \nRead access is used to populate the \"My Day\" interface in Hive with calendar events and details. It is also used to allow syncing of calendar events to Hive Notes. Write access is used to respond to events from \"My Day\" and schedule events from Hive Actions.\n \nShared access is used to help users avoid conflict when using Scheduling.\n\n### Hive Apps - Mail (Office 365)\n \nThe \"Mail\" Hive App allows for seamless integration of your Microsoft 365 email account so you can access your inbox, send new messages, organize email follow-ups, and more , all without ever leaving Hive.\n\nThe scope(s) required for the integration to function are listed below:\n \n**Scope**\n \n**Permission**\n \n**How it's used by Hive**\n \n Files.ReadWrite.All\n \nHave full access to all files user can access\n \nRead access is used to fetch OneDrive file data for adding attachments to emails sent from inside of Hive.           "content": "Plan & execute company initiatives | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢ **     Use Cases Plan & execute company initiatives \n# Plan & execute company initiatives\n \nKeep everyone rowing in the same direction with Hive projects, templates & amazing teamwork\n Written by Erin Gouveia Updated over 5 months ago  \n Company-wide initiatives exist across companies of all types and sizes. Use this quick-start guide to get started in Hive and optimize your project flow and structure.\n\nDo any of these issues sound familiar?\n \nI don't understand the macro-level initiatives my company is planning.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nI don't know who is working on what tasks within a larger projects.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nWhat's the next step after I complete this small task?\n \n‚Ä¢ \nCan I see a high-level view of what's going on in the organization?\n \n# Step 1: Define the Initiative **\n \nIf you can relate to any of the questions above, this article is for you. Let's first think about the types of initiatives your team is taking on. Which of the following are they?\n \n‚Ä¢ \n**Micro-level: On-going, repeatable initiatives that exist within a department** (i.e. HR team onboarding, legal team reviewing materials for sign-off)\n \n‚Ä¢ \n**Macro-level: Department initiatives undergone to achieve KPIs**\n \nGood news -- you can tackle both of these initiatives in Hive. Once you understand the type of initiative you're working on, you can get started on the moving parts and tasks within.\n\nFirst we need to ask ourselves a few questions. To start, we want to better understand how your team has learned about this initiative.\n\nWas it...\n \n‚Ä¢ \nTriggered by an event in the company\n \n‚Ä¢ \nAn ongoing project that your team is running for the company \n \n‚Ä¢ \nA repeatable tasks that exists or pops-up every week\n \n‚Ä¢ \nA response to requests from other teams or departments \n \n‚Ä¢ \nGiven to the team by leadership\n\n# **Step 2: Sketch It Out in Hive**\n \nOnce we understand what triggered the event, we can take the appropriate actions in Hive. \n\n**If the task was triggered by an event in the company:**\n \n‚Ä¢ \nCreate a new project in Hive for the initiative or task and invite all relevant team members from your organization.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nTo add a new project, click the \"New\" button in the upper right-hand corner of your Hive window and select New Project.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nYou'll need to add teammates to your project. To do this, click the \"Edit Project\" button in Hive and press the \"Add project members\". They'll now be able to access and visualize this initiative.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIf there are relevant documents or additional information, you can attach them in the Project Overview. Access Project Overview by clicking the Overview button when you're inside the project.\n \nAnother component of Hive that you might want to utilize if a task is triggered by an event in the company is Sections.\n\nEvery project goes through a process from start to finish. In some industries, this process is marked by stages. For example, a consulting project might have three section: planning, execution, and closing.\n \n**To use sections in Hive:\n \n‚Ä¢ \nWhen adding sections to a new project **, go to the project navigator, select \"+ New Project\", create the project, click More menu at the top right corner, then scroll down to find the Section, then click \"Add section\".\n \n‚Ä¢ \nWhen you create a new action, it ** adds it to the New section by default **. You change an action's section by clicking the dropdown menu at the top of the action card.\n \nOnce you've set up Sections, you can use them in a few ways:\n \n‚Ä¢ \nFilter all actions in Kanban by status\n \n‚Ä¢ \nView actions broken down by sections in Gantt view\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIn Gantt view, you can also group actions by section\n \n**If the task is an ongoing project that your team is running for the company:**\n \n‚Ä¢ \nThis setup is going to look largely the same as the previous, except you will be adding tasks to a preexisting project.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIf you need to add team members to the project, click the \"Edit Project\" button in Hive and add \"Members\" to your project. They'll now be able to access and visualize this initiative.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nTo add team members to the specific task, you can either tag them in the comments of the action card, or add them as followers by clicking the blue plus sign on the bottom right hand corner.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIf the task is part of a collection of tasks that can all be created using the same framework, it could be beneficial to use Hive Templates.\n \nWith templates, you can easily create built-out action cards that have pre-existing content, making it easier for your teammates to understand next steps and action items.\n\nTo access Hive Templates:\n \n‚Ä¢ \nGo to your main menu (upper right corner under your profile picture)\n \n‚Ä¢ \nClick \"Workspace Settings\"\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSelect \"Templates\"\n \n‚Ä¢ \nClick \"+ Create New Action Template\"\n \n‚Ä¢ \nName the template and provide a label if desired\n \n‚Ä¢ \nAdd the subactions, assignees, days, and durations. It will look something like the below. \n \nTo apply a Hive Template, simply open up the action card (or create a new one) and select \"Apply Action Template\" from the dropdown.\n\n**If it is a repeatable task that occurs weekly:**\n \n‚Ä¢ \nWithin your new project, add a task and set the individual action as recurring\n \n‚Ä¢ \nTo make an action recurring, simply click on the \"Due Date\" section of the action card, and click \"Set Recurring\"\n \n**If the task was in response to requests from other teams or departments:**\n\nThere are a few ways to digest tasks passed from a team or department. If the task is coming from another teammate, and you've received it over email, you can easily use Hive Mail to either:\n \n‚Ä¢ \n**Create a new task from the email.** To do this, simply click into the email from your Hive Mail inbox, then click the checkmark icon above the message. You‚Äôll then be able to access it from My Actions.\n \n**Bonus:** Email threads linked to action cards are dynamic, so they will update with any additional replies that are sent or received. Anyone who has access to the action card will be able to view and reply to the linked messages, ensuring that everyone stays up to date with the latest.\n \n‚Ä¢ \n**Pull information in on the task from a Hive Form.** This is an easy way to intake project or task data in a repeatable fashion. \n \nHere's how to enable and utilize Hive Forms:\n \n‚Ä¢ \nEnable \"Forms\" from \"Hive Apps\" if it's not already enabled. Pin Forms to your left-hand navigation panel.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nForms will now be easily accessible. To create a new Form, simply click \"Create A New Form\" on the upper right hand corner.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nUtilize the Form builder to compile the information for your Form.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSet where you want to receive the Form submissions. You can either receive each submission via email, or in a Hive action ( it will automatically create an action in Hive in the project and assigned to the person you select) \n \n Each form come with a link that you can share or post on a website. Click the button \"copy\" to save it to your clipboard. \n\n**If the task was given to you by leadership:**\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIf a task is passed down to you by leadership as part of a larger initiative, it's easy to add yourself to the existing project that they're working from.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nOnce you're in the project, you can work with them to learn more about project set-up, milestones, KPIs, and other components of the project.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIt would be helpful to view a macro-level initiative in Gantt view to better understand the tasks, dependencies, and any other moving parts that are involved.\n \nTo view a project in Gantt view, simply enter your project and click the \"Change Layout\" button on the top right. From the dropdown, select Gantt.For a clearer structure, you can group your actions by phases in the Gantt view; navigate to your view settings and select \"Group by Phase.\" Adjust these settings to visually organize your project into logical segments for better tracking.\n\nWithin Gantt view, you'll even be able to customize the tasks and projects to your liking. Here are a few things you can do:\n \n‚Ä¢ \n**Change the timeline** - Gantt view is defaulted to show you a timeline of several months, but you can change it. You can zoom in to look a a few weeks or zoom out to look at a project over a whole year or several years.\n \n‚Ä¢ \n**Go full screen** - If you want to make your Gantt view bigger, you can expand it to cover your whole screen.\n \n‚Ä¢ \n**Change assignees** - Easily assign yourself or your teammates tasks within the larger Gantt view by selecting the task and editing assignee.\n \n‚Ä¢ \n**Add dependencies** - Dependencies are tasks that depend on the completion of another to be started/completed themselves. To add a dependency, locate the circle on the right hand side of each task and drag to the beginning of the next action.\n \n‚Ä¢ \n**Add milestones **- Milestones are an easy way to track major accomplishments in your project. They are generally used as a indicator to call out a significant event on your Gantt Chart such as a project launch, key deliverable, or presentation date. To add a milestone, click the flag icon to mark each task as a milestone within an action card. The milestone will then show up as a diamond on the Gantt chart.6. **Group by Phase** - Easily organize and view your project timeline by grouping tasks into phases. To group by phase, adjust your view settings and select \"Group by Phase.\" This functionality provides a clear overview of each project segment and allows for better timeline management.\n \n# **Step 3: Check Out The Big Picture**\n \nNow that we understand how projects can be set up in Hive, it's time to think about the big picture. How can we better understand what's going on in our projects as they progress? There are a few ways to do that in Hive.\n\n## Portfolio View\n \nFirst, there's Portfolio View. This view is the all-in-one place to see the detail of Project Navigator combined with the flexibility of a Table View. \n\nTo access Portfolio View, you'll need to turn it on in Hive Apps, which you can access under \"Apps\" on your left-hand side navigator. The beauty of Portfolio View is that it lets you view actions from across projects, actions, and subactions in once place. This is ideal for teammates who want to better understand how the big-picture is progressing and how initiatives are working together.\n\nTo create a Portfolio View:\n \n‚Ä¢ \nFirst select the projects you want to include in the view from the \"Add projects\" dropdown.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSelect items from the dropdown for \"Project details and fields\" so you can better understand which items you'd like included in the Portfolio View.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nUtilize the dropdown that says \"Add actions and subactions\" to pull in the status of the actions and subactions that are living across projects listed on the left. The due date for those actions appears, and a checkmark if they are completed. Now both are available in your drop down! \n\nTo share a view with others, head to the share icon on the right and add your teammates to the Portfolio View.\n\nOverall, Portfolio View is best leveraged when looking at multiple projects that have the same action cards and/or custom fields because you can then compare those projects accurately and efficiently.\n \n## **Dashboards\n \nDashboards are another way you can understand the big-picture and track tasks across the organization or team. To enable Dashboards, visits Hive Apps and toggle the Dashboards tile on.\n\nFrom there, you'll be able access your Workspace Overview **dashboard which will help you** **better understand progress across teams and your organization.\n\n## Risks and Issues Tracker\n \nAnother great tool that you can use in Hive to manage initiatives as they unfold is the risk and issues tracker functionality. \n\nTo turn on this aspect of Hive, simply visit Hive Apps and toggle on \"Risks and Issues Tracker.\" Your team can now use the tracker to manage the risks and issues in each of your projects in one centralized location.\n\nTo add a new issue, open the tracker and enter the name of the risk you would like to keep track of.           "content": "Manage complex project timelines | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢ **     Use Cases Manage complex project timelines \n# Manage complex project timelines\n \nAn powerful tool for the PMO & the PMO within all of us\n Written by Erin Gouveia Updated over 2 months ago  \nHive has everything you need to manage large-scale, multi-workstream project plans and with this get-started guide, we'll have your timeline loaded into Hive in no time.\n\nLet's get started!\n\n# Step 1: Where is your project plan now? **\n \n**a) It's in another tool & I'm planning to import it**\n \nGreat, hop over to our Import Guide to review the steps, and come back here once you've imported it\n\n**b) I'm starting from scratch**\n \nOk, let's get you started by creating a New Project (New > Project) with:\n \nTitle\n \n‚Ä¢ \nDue date\n \n‚Ä¢ \nGantt layout\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSections: hold off for now, we will get to that next\n \n‚Ä¢ \nShared with: we recommend starting with just yourself for now, but our Draft Mode works well if you'd like to add your teammates but not notify them of assignments until you're finished with the plan. \n \n**Tip:** once your project is created, click the configure menu to change the available columns and filters\n\n# **Step 2: Map out the workstreams **\n \n## How does your project naturally 'break down':\n \n**a) By major Stage or Sections of work, with individual steps within these sections owned by specific teams or departments**\n \nIf this is the case, we recommend that you set up Sections within your project to be those major lifecycle stages that everything in your project can be categorized into.\n\nSections are added by going to More > Edit Project > and adding the sections there.\n\nYou can then enter actions into the sections, when you group by section or drag existing actions into your sections:\n\n**b) By Workstream or Department: each team runs their own segment of this overall project and we don't organize into the same lifecycle stage across all work streams. **\n\nIn this case, we recommend that if your Department work streams are more than 30 specific tasks, that these be all labeled the same, and then you view your timeline grouped by Label rather than by Section. Create the labels directly on the action cards using the '+' icon. Here's everything about labels to learn more. \n\n# **Step 3: Configure your gantt to work for you **üòÄ\n \n## If any of these would make your life easier - proceed as directed!\n \n‚Ä¢ \n**I'd like the gantt timeline to auto-adjust my dates: if one date shifts, subsequent dates should be auto-scheduled by Hive** üëâ Turn on Auto-scheduling , or even Strict Auto-scheduling (see link for more).\n\n‚Ä¢ \n**I'd like Hive to show my action card as completed if all the subactions are completed, automatically **üëâ Toggle on this setting in the Edit Project screen:\n\n‚Ä¢ \n**I'd like Hive to calculate the start and end date of my parent actions, based on the earliest & latest dates of the subactions** üëâ Toggle on this setting in the Edit Project screen:\n\n‚Ä¢ \n**I'd like to be able to view all milestones across all projects at once** üëâ Flip those action cards into Milestones and then create your Milestone Report . \n\n# **Step 4: Add your actions into the project**\n\nUse the prompts on the gantt chart to enter your actions one-by-one, or did you know you can copy + paste from a list and Hive will generate separate actions?\n\n# **Step 5: Inviting the team & assigning work**\n \nNow, for the do-ers of your project plan. Head to the Invites section to invite everyone who is responsible to complete a part of this project plan . \n\nRemember, your internal team members within your organization would be regular members, while external parties who may need access to a single project or who are outside of your organization, could be External Users . \n\nWith everyone assigned out their work, it's time to begin! üìà\n\nOnce work is assigned, team members can refer to their My Actions page to see their action and task assignments across all of their projects.\n\n# **Step 6: Gain Approval for Deliverables**\n \nIf your deliverables need to go through an internal or external review process, leverage the proofing and approval capabilities in Hive to receive feedback and track approvals.\n\nUpload files for review in the Hive Proofing tool where multiple team members can simultaneously conduct a review, adding comments and markups in real-time.\n\nCreate approval routes that go to multiple users, teams, as well as external approvers (those without Hive accounts).\n\nWhen it's your turn to review, you'll receive a notification and the request for your approval will appear on your My Actions page to easily tracker all of your approval requests.\n\n# **For additional power-ups, we recommend:**\n \n‚Ä¢ \nKicking off the project with Running a Great Meeting \n \n‚Ä¢ \nKeeping track of key dates in Portfolio View \n \n‚Ä¢ \nNoting any major concerns through our Risks & Issues Tracker \n Related Articles Gantt charts Plan & execute company initiatives New this Week in Hive: June 2021 List View: A New Project View in Hive Home View: List View (New)!  üòû üòê üòÉ \n‚Ä¢ Sign In \n‚Ä¢ Forgot Password? \n‚Ä¢ API \n‚Ä¢ \n‚Ä¢",

          "content": "Run a modern agency on Hive | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢ **     Use Cases Run a modern agency on Hive \n# Run a modern agency on Hive\n \nLeverage Hive to enable your Agency workflow from end to end\n Written by Dee Miller Updated over a year ago  \nHive can support every step in your campaign lifecycle from brief to progress reporting. With our step by step guide you can get your campaigns set up ready to go, tracking included. \n\nLet's get started!\n\n# Step 1: How do your work requests, campaigns or projects begin? Let‚Äôs build a seamless work request and briefing system for you.**\n \nWhen initiating projects or campaigns, work generally begins with a brief or request. Create a ** Hive Form ** to capture the request and move away from inconsistent email and duplicate documents. Hive offers you the option of creating an action card in an intake project, ready for triage or creating a project directly from the submission. \n\nTypes of request great for Hive forms:\n \nNew client brief submission\n \n‚Ä¢ \nCreative resource or support requests\n \n‚Ä¢ \nAd hoc client requests\n \n‚Ä¢ \nAd Ops Trafficking\n \nHere is an example of a creative resource request and a new campaign brief:\n\n**Hive Form to Action card **\n\nIn the below example, the Hive Form is used to collect resource requests for a creative team. The Hive form is creating an action card with the request details for additional resource and landing this in a specific project ready for the triage and assignment:\n\n**Hive Form to Project** \n\nIn the below example, the Hive Form collects the briefing information and creates a campaign from a template, ready for the media team to start work. \n\n# **Step 2: Set up your Project Navigator and utilise Project Custom Fields for specific campaign information. **\n \nThe project structure must reflect how you organize and execute work. Hive provides you with the flexibility to create a ** project hierarchy **that‚Äôs right for you and your team. \n\nDetermine the structure that‚Äôs right for your team by thinking about how the work is structured:\n \n‚Ä¢ \nLine of business\n \n‚Ä¢ \nChannel\n \n‚Ä¢ \nProject-based\n \n‚Ä¢ \nCampaign-based\n\n**Top Tip:** Create specific guidelines for your Hive users to explain any require naming conventions for your campaigns or projects when applying a template or creating a project. \n\n**Project Custom Fields**\n\nFor custom campaign data that you‚Äôd like to track and see displayed on the Project Navigator, project views and included in the Portfolio view, setting up ** Project Custom Fields ** can be incredibly useful. \n\nCampaign data can include:\n \n‚Ä¢ \nCampaign Budget\n \n‚Ä¢ \nChannel\n \n‚Ä¢ \nCampaign Tier\n \n‚Ä¢ \nClient name\n \n‚Ä¢ \nClient line of business or product\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSLA details\n \n‚Ä¢ \nExec Sponsor\n\nHere's how to set one up:\n \n‚Ä¢ \nGo to the project where you want to add a custom field\n \n‚Ä¢ \nGo to the 'More' menu in the upper right\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSelect 'Create custom field'\n \n‚Ä¢ \nType the name of the field you want to add, select the field kind & type\n \n‚Ä¢ \nHit 'Save'.\n\n# **Step 3: Create a non-campaign or ad-hoc projects to capture tasks outside of your campaigns; support this with a label for easy reporting. **\n \nFrom time to time, tasks and work will occur that is outside of the campaign template. It can help track these for review, assignment or including in your campaign update or QBR with clients.\n\nWe recommend creating an Ad Hoc ** project ** where team members can create action cards corresponding to any non-campaign or ad-hoc work requests at a client or channel level. \n\nDoing this will allow you visibility into additional work requests that may be aligned to your organisation‚Äôs channels but not specific to any client. Projects are large initiatives or groups of initiatives that can be organized into hierarchies and will contain all the tasks your team needs to do. \n\nThese Projects are visible and accessible on your left-side panel under Project Navigator.\n\nEach project has **unique permissions,** meaning that if a non-Admin user is not added, they do not see it, nor can they access its tasks. You can find the location bar either by clicking the Project's name when it is open or by clicking the pencil icon when hovering over it in Project Navigator. \n\n## Action Cards\n\nAction Cards, also known as Actions, Cards, or Tasks, are the core element of Hive and the most important object you and your team will be creating. As a project manager, I add details like labels and dependencies while my employees review and complete their tasks, moving them through various statuses. \n\nAn average assignee will most likely only be viewing what they are being asked to do, moving tasks between statuses, and adding comments/attachments. Will I be creating all the tasks for my employees upfront, or let them create their own?\n \n‚Ä¢ \nWhat information is needed on my action cards?\n \n‚Ä¢ \nHow can I make my action card format repeatable?\n\n### Best Practices Break:\n\nHive is customizable, meaning each user can define how they view the tool.           "content": "Action card priorities | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢ **     Using Hive Action Cards Action card priorities \n# Action card priorities\n \nAdaptable to how your team works: create, set & sort your priorities\n Written by Erin Gouveia Updated over 5 months ago  \nOne of the most requested features on our Feature Request page was the ability to set priority on action cards, and we're excited to announce that it's here - thank you for using your voice, Hive Community! \n\nWith priority levels on your action cards, you can now:\n \nSee a priority level indicator on the outside of cards in any project's card ** layout - aka, Status, Team or Label View\n \n‚Ä¢ \nCreate a customized priority list - including colors!           "content": "Action templates | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢ **     Using Hive Action Cards Action templates \n# Action templates\n \nUpdate action details in just a few clicks using templates\n Written by Erin Gouveia Updated over 5 months ago  \nYou can create action templates to easily add subactions, assignees, due dates, and dependencies to your action cards. Action templates can help you quickly update tasks that tend to repeat throughout your projects and keep consistency across the workspace.\n \nAdditionally, these templates can also be automatically applied using forms or project settings for more streamlined workflows.\n\n# To create an action template:\n \nGo to your main menu (upper right corner)\n \n‚Ä¢ \nClick \"Settings\"\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSelect \"Templates\"\n \n‚Ä¢ \nMake sure you are in the \"Action Card\" menu\n \n‚Ä¢ \nClick \"Create action template\"\n \n‚Ä¢ \nName the template and provide a label if desired\n \n‚Ä¢ \nAdd the subactions, assignees, days, and durations. It will look something like the below. You can add further levels of subactions onto your action templates too!\n \nThen you just save the action template and you're done!\n \n You can also create an action template straight from an action card, using the 'Save as template' option underneath the More menu on the right:\n\n# Setting due dates on action templates\n \nTo ensure deadlines are included when you apply an action template, make sure that the 'Automatically add due dates' option is checked. ‚Äã\n \n We will refer to the image above for the examples below \n\nAssuming you've used positive and negative deadlines, there are two different scenarios to which deadlines will be applied:\n\n## 1. If your main action card already has a deadline set, at the moment that you apply the action template:\n \nSince you have already applied the deadline to the action, Hive is smart to know that you need to complete the action by that specific date. Hive will set any subaction in your action template that is listed as 'Day 0' as equal** to the parent action due date.¬†\n\nAll negative days will happen before the action due date and all positive days will happen after the action due date, following the same pattern.\n\nUsing the above example for the Blog Post action template, if you have **set** the action card's deadline to 15 Jan **before** applying the template, when you apply the Blog Post action template:\n \n‚Ä¢ \n\"Draft\" will be set for 13 Jan (minus 2 days before 15 Jan)¬†\n \n‚Ä¢ \n\"Review\" will be set for 14 Jan (minus 1 day before 15 Jan)\n \n‚Ä¢ \n\"Finalize & Post\" will be set for 15 Jan (Day 0)\n \n‚Ä¢ \n\"Analyze Post Traffic\" will be set for 21 Jan (plus 6 days after 15 Jan)\n \n## 2. If your action does not currently have a deadline set when you apply the action template:\n \nSince you have enabled deadlines and your action currently has no deadline, Hive assumes that the subaction marked as 'Day 0' in the action template is today.\n\nUsing the above example for the Blog Post action template, if today is 17 Dec:\n \n‚Ä¢ \n\"Draft\" will be set for 15 Dec (minus 2 days before today)\n \n‚Ä¢ \n\"Review\" will be set for 16 Dec (minus 1 day before today)\n \n‚Ä¢ \n\"Finalize & Post\" will be set for 17 Dec (today)\n \n‚Ä¢ \n\"Analyze Post Traffic\" will be set for 23 Dec (6 days after today)\n\n# Adding dependencies to the template\n \nNot only can you automatically add deadlines, you can also set up dependencies . So if one step can't move forward without the completion of another, it can be useful to set one up.¬†\n\nJust click the \"Add dependency\" link. It will open a search box where you type the name of the step you want this step to be dependent on and select add. It will then show the dependency in bright yellow with the option to remove.¬†\n\n# Adding approval rounds to the template\n \nIf your action will need an approval process, you can include an approval template within your action template. ( Note: you will need to first save the approval template by setting up the approval round and clicking Save as template under the More menu ).\n\nOnce you have the approval template, you can add it to your action template here towards the bottom of the modal.\n\n# Adding an action template to a card\n \nBefore applying an action template, you can also manually create action cards. Navigate to the project workspace, click on the **New (+)** button in the toolbar, and customize your action card for the specific needs of your project.\n \nClick the blue + New button next to the search bar to create a new action card, then select \"Apply Template\" under the More menu towards the right.\n\nFrom the searchable popup, click the name of the template you would like to apply. It will create the subactions and add the assignees, due dates, and dependencies from your template.\n\n# Adding multiple action templates to a card\n \nYou can now layer multiple action templates on a single action card. To do so:\n \n‚Ä¢ \nApply the first action template to the card.¬†\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSelect a second action template from the dropdown list.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nHive will add in all of the subactions, due dates, assignees, and attachments from the second action template. All data from the first template will also remain!¬†\n \n# Applying action template to multiple actions at once\n \nIf you want to apply the same template to actions in bulk, you can do it in Table view. All you have to do is to select actions, right-click and select 'Apply action template'. \n \nAlternatively, action templates can be pre-applied to cards using the \"Use action template\" option in project settings. Configure this to automatically apply templates to new cards created via forms, ensuring consistency and saving time.\n\n Related Articles Action Template ‚Äî Deadlines New this Week in Hive: June 2021 New This Week in Hive: August 2021 New This Week in Hive: November 2021 New This Week in Hive: December 2021  üòû üòê üòÉ \n‚Ä¢ Sign In \n‚Ä¢ Forgot Password? \n‚Ä¢ API \n‚Ä¢ \n‚Ä¢",

          "content": "Project layouts | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢ **     Using Hive Projects Project layouts \n# Project layouts\n \nThe 7 types of layouts and when you should use each\n Written by Erin Gouveia Updated over a year ago  \nHive offers 7 different ways to view a Hive project and this will give you an overview of each:\n \n Status view \n \n‚Ä¢ \n Team view \n \n‚Ä¢ \n Calendar \n \n‚Ä¢ \n Label view \n \n‚Ä¢ \n Gantt chart \n \n‚Ä¢ \n Table view \n \n‚Ä¢ \n List view \n \nWithin the project, you can toggle between the views at any time** and even have **multiple people in the same project each working in a different layout**. Everyone will see the information and **updates in real-time, no matter which layout** they are in!\n\nEach layout can be helpful depending on what your team is working on and how you like to organize your work.¬† So how do you know which one to choose?\n\nIn this article, we'll provide guidance on the pros and cons of each layout. So that the next time you make a project you can choose your layout with confidence.¬†\n\n# **1. Status view**\n \n In status view, all of your project's action cards are organized in lists that each represent a \"status\" in your workflow. Your actions move horizontally across the lists from unstarted to completed. You can customize the status columns to fit your team's exact specifications. \n\n**When is status view helpful?**\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIf you prefer a **visual workflow**, status view lets you see at a glance the progress of a project.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIf the actions in your project **all go through the same statuses**, it makes a lot of sense to use a status view.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIf your team uses **Agile methods**, status view is best suited to organizing and managing sprints.\n \nThose are just a few of the instances status view can be useful. In terms of downsides, status view doesn't emphasize deadlines as much as other views, and it can be a little more difficult to break it down by team member or label.¬†\n\n**A note on statuses:**\n\nAs mentioned above, actions in status view move horizontally from one list to another. The default set of statuses is unstarted -> in progress -> completed. However, you can add new statuses to completely customize how your project is organized. The easiest way to add a status is to scroll over to the right of your project, add the name of your status in the text box, and press enter.\n\nHere are some examples of sets of statuses that your team could use:\n \n‚Ä¢ \n**Blog publishing** - unstarted -> ideas -> writing -> editing -> add images -> published -> share on social media -> completed\n \n‚Ä¢ \n**Agile sprint** - unstarted -> this week -> in progress -> needs review -> completed\n \n‚Ä¢ \n**Hiring funnel **- unstarted -> reviewed application -> selected for phone interview -> phone interview scheduled -> selected for on-site interview -> on-site interview scheduled -> hired -> completed\n\n# **2. Team view**\n \n In team view, all your actions are organized under columns with each list representing a team member. ¬†You can reassign actions to other team members with a simple drag and drop, and add new actions onto someone's list with ease. \n\n**When is team view helpful?**\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIt's great for managers who want an easy way to **assess team workload**.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIf actions often move from one person to another, it is super **easy to move actions between team members** in team view.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nYou can keep from putting too much on people's list by **adding tasks to the unassigned** column. That way the first person to have some free time can pick it up by dragging it onto their list.¬†\n \nThese are just a few reasons of why having a team view can help you move your project forward.\n\nTeam view is not as helpful if you need to see the status of your actions or if you are working on a project by yourself.\n\n# **3. Calendar view**\n \n In calendar view , you can see all the actions in your project organized by deadline. You can simply drag and drop to change an action's deadline. The default view shows all actions due for the next six weeks. \n\n Hive calendar also allows you to **one-way sync **to Google Calendar, Outlook, and iCal. \n\n**When is calendar view helpful?**\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIf you want your team to **focus on deadlines**, a calendar makes it easy to keep them top of mind.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIf you want to be able to **view your actions on your email calendar **as well, this view is the only one that allows you to do that.¬†\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIf you want **all the actions you add to have deadlines**, it's super easy to do on the calendar. You can just click the date and it automatically opens a task with that deadline.¬†\n \nCalendar view is awesome! The only cases where it's not as useful are when you want to be able to view key details of your actions on the front of the card. In calendar view, only the title and the assignee of the action shows. It's also harder to see who on your team is working on what for the same reason.¬†\n\n# **4. Label view**\n \n In label view, all your actions are organized under lists with each list representing a different label. ¬†You can change the label of an action with a simple drag and drop, and add new actions to a label with ease. \n\nLabels in Hive are essential tags you can add to action cards that make it easier to distinguish between different actions in a project.¬†\n\n**When is label view helpful?**\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIf your **team uses several labels**, this layout can be a great way to assess your workflow across initiatives.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIf you want to **easily add labels to new actions **you create, all you have to do is type in an action in the text box of the label you want to add.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIf your team prefers a **visual workflow**, it helps that each action comes with a color that can make it easier spot the differences between them.\n \nLabel view is not as helpful if your team doesn't really use labels or you want to be able to easily see who is responsible for an action.¬†\n\n# **5. Gantt Chart**\n \n In Gantt, all your actions are laid out in a chart where each line represents something you want to do. These actions correspond to dates where the start and endpoint of the action represents the timeline it is expected to be completed. You can drag and drop to change the timeline and simply click to add a new action.¬† \n\nGantt charts includes the ability to zoom into to take a closer look and add dependencies when needed.\n\n**When is Gantt Chart helpful?**\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIf you are trying to plan out how long a project will take, Gantt is a perfect way to assess that.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIf you have a clear understanding of the steps involved in completing the goal, it is really easy to lay out in a chart form.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIf you need to be able to share your plan with people outside your organization, Gantt allows you to export your work to PDF, PNG or XLS.\n \nGantt view is so great for planning, but not as useful if you run in an agile framework where you never really can predict specific timelines.\n\n# **6. Table View**\n \n In Table View, all your actions are laid out in a table (like a spreadsheet). These actions can be sorted and filtered accordingly to your needs and preferences. You can easily edit the text or change the fields by clicking on it.¬† \n \n \"\n \n Additionally, you can use filters on the column titles to filter many of the actions. Columns can be re-arranged or toggled on and off for your preferences. \n\nWhen is Table View useful?\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIf you are to do a multiple sort/filter. Say you want to see all actions that are unstated but overdue, you can do so quickly and flexibly in Table View.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nWhen you want to see a list of actions and make changes quickly. In table View, you can edit the field by clicking on it.¬†\n \nTable View is so great for quick editing and filtering. However, it is important to know that first-time users may feel overwhelmed by Table View. Know that a table view is useful when you know exactly what you want.¬†\n\n# **7. List View**\n \nOur newest Project Layout List View brings the convenience of a list (think My Actions View, but for any project) with customizable filters. Think: one expanded list of all actions in your project that can be customized, filtered, and edited to fit your workflow, preferences, and needs.\n\nLike Table View, List View columns with Status, Labels, etc, will all be editable directly from the column themselves.           "content": "List View: A New Project View in Hive | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢ **     Using Hive Projects List View: A New Project View in Hive \n# List View: A New Project View in Hive\n Written by Michaela Rollings Updated over 4 months ago  \nThis week we're launching List View,** and it's not every day we launch a brand new project view. \n\nWith this new view, we're bringing the convenience of a list into your Hive projects - if you like Home View, this will be your new favorite.\n\nThink: one expanded list of all actions in your project that can be customized, filtered, and edited to fit your workflow, preferences, and needs. \n\n**‚Äã\n \nTo access List View and test it out for yourself, just create a new tab with our swanky new tabs feature and select List View. \n\nIf you want this List View to be private, just slide the \"Private view\" toggle on the bottom of the dropdown.\n\nAt the top right, you'll find the Configure view settings:**\n \n Group By section : by default, the List view will be organized by Status, but with a few clicks, you can configure the list view to group by:\n \nStatus\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSection\n \n‚Ä¢ \nPriority Level\n \n‚Ä¢ \nProject/subproject\n \n‚Ä¢ \nPhase\n \n‚Ä¢ \n Filter section: provides a variety of different filters such as Statuses, Assignees, Dates, Labels, etc.\n \n‚Ä¢ \n Display section: \n \nColumns: One of the ways to select which columns to display.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nBlocked actions: Blocked / Unblocked / Show both\n \n‚Ä¢ \nMilestones: Milestone / No Milestone / Show both\n \n‚Ä¢ \nArchived actions check box\n \n‚Ä¢ \nProjects in draft mode check box\n \n‚Ä¢ \nEmpty groups check box: if your Section/Project/Status, etc doesn't have any actions under it, you'll want to check this box to allow Hive to show that empty Section/Project/Status in your view.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nUnbundle subactions: Do not show subactions unless they're grouped under parent actions\n \n‚Ä¢ \nHide subactions: Do not show subactions when they're not grouped under parent actions\n \nBringing special attention to Sections. Think of sections as your guide to your most pressing actions now and in the future.\n\nCreate your custom sections and drag & drop your actions in there. \n\nPlease note: these are shared sections meaning everyone in the project will see them.\n\nAlso, you can easily expand/collapse your actions & their subactions by using the +/- buttons in the List view:\n\nYou can also select entire Sections to bulk-update action cards. Simply click on the checkbox next to the Section name to allow Hive to select all actions under that Section for you.\n\nCurrently, sections exist in List, Gantt and Table views, but stay tuned for more!\n\nThe columns to the right of each action are moveable - just click and drag one column to bring it closer or further away from the action card name.\n\nThe full list of columns supported in List view:\n \n‚Ä¢ \nAction name\n \n‚Ä¢ \nAssignees\n \n‚Ä¢ \nStart Date\n \n‚Ä¢ \nDue Date\n \n‚Ä¢ \nLabels\n \n‚Ä¢ \nStatus\n \n‚Ä¢ \nProject\n \n‚Ä¢ \nParent project\n \n‚Ä¢ \nPriority\n \n‚Ä¢ \nBlocked\n \n‚Ä¢ \nUrgent\n \n‚Ä¢ \nAttachments\n \n‚Ä¢ \nComments\n \n‚Ä¢ \nMilestone\n \n‚Ä¢ \nPhase\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSection\n \n‚Ä¢ \nStory Points\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSimple ID\n \n‚Ä¢ \nCreated By\n \n‚Ä¢ \nCreated Date\n \n‚Ä¢ \nModified By\n \n‚Ä¢ \nModified Date\n \n‚Ä¢ \nAssigned By \n \n‚Ä¢ \nAssigned Date\n \n‚Ä¢ \nCompleted By\n \n‚Ä¢ \nCompleted Date\n \n‚Ä¢ \nEstimate\n \n‚Ä¢ \nTotal Time Tracked\n \n‚Ä¢ \nEstimated Time Spent\n \n‚Ä¢ \nAction Custom Fields\n \n‚Ä¢ \nDescription\n \n‚Ä¢ \nDuration\n \nOnly in List View, you'll be able to see the percentage of estimates spent by logged time.\n\nFeel free to enable the columns and filter by each to customize your view. \n\nLike Table View, List View columns with Status, Labels, etc, will all be editable directly from the column themselves.           "content": "Meet the Hive action card | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢ **    Getting Started Getting to know Hive Meet the Hive action card \n# Meet the Hive action card\n \nLearn the basics about action cards.\n A Written by Alexander Heldring Updated over 5 months ago \nThe action card is your home base for important details and collaboration. \n\nThe card makes it easy to quickly gather the most important details of any assignment. In the right column** you‚Äôll see who is assigned to the action, when it‚Äôs due, and what the card‚Äôs status is. \n\nIf you'd like the action card to appear as an event in your Google/Outlook Calendar, you can use the 'Schedule time' option under the Dates section in the card. To make the 'Schedule time' option appear, you'll make sure you have Hive Calendar connected in your Hive Apps. \n\nThe pop-out will show your Calendar availability, including existing events and you'll be able to choose a suitable time slot. The event will appear in your Calendar with the same name as the action card title.\n\nTo schedule an event for both you and your teammate/-s, you can add them to the guest list. Hive will then show the full Calendar availability of each team member you add ‚Äì making it easier than ever before to schedule time for meetings, check-ins, and more!\n\nUse the following options to easily add your event data to the action card as well:\n \nAdd to estimated time - add event time duration to the Estimated time section on the card;\n \n‚Ä¢ \nAdd users as assignees - set all guests as assignees on the card;\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSet as action due date - use the event date as a new due date for your action card.\n\n**Note**: this feature works for both Google & Outlook Calendars, however, Outlook users can only schedule time for their own calendar, not search for others' availability.\n\nThe** top bar** of the action card tells you which project it‚Äôs in, and the bar‚Äôs color represents the project color. **Move the card **to a new project by clicking on the caret next to the project‚Äôs name. \n\nTo mark your card as **urgent**, access action templates , convert your action, or use other great features, head over to the 'More' menu at the top right of the card.\n\nPlease note that it's possible to change your action's status color. All you need to do is open up the Statuses dropdown and hit the pencil icon next to the Status you want to change the color for.** **\n\n**Note: since this is a global setting, the color will be changed in every action card with that status in your workspace. Keep this in mind when changing common statutes like \"In Progress\" or \"Completed\".**\n\nQuickly share, delete, archive, or add followers to your action from the bottom right of the card. \n\n Following the card means you will get notifications in your activity feed for things like comments, status updates, and date changes. Assignees will automatically become followers. **‚Äã Use the comments section on the bottom left of the card to collaborate with your teammates. When you @mention someone, they will automatically be added as a follower. You can use the @action and @project shortcuts to automatically send a direct mention notification to all action card followers, and all project members, respectively. \n\nTo see the history **of your card, click on the 'Show history' option at the bottom left of the card. ‚Äã\n\nFinally, if you would like to adjust the Hive Apps that are visible on your action cards, head to the Edit Project menu (More > Edit Project > Advanced settings) and select which Apps should appear for this project:\n\nNote: the options available will depend on which Hive Apps you have turned on or connected in your workspace.\n\n Related Articles Create a Jira issue from Hive New This Week in Hive: August 2021 New This Week in Hive: October 2021 New This Week in Hive: November 2021 Adding Holidays & OOO Calendars into Hive  üòû üòê üòÉ \n‚Ä¢ Sign In \n‚Ä¢ Forgot Password? \n‚Ä¢ API \n‚Ä¢ \n‚Ä¢",

          "content": "Project Navigator | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢ **     Using Hive Projects Project Navigator \n# Project Navigator\n \nNavigate between all of your active and archived projects\n Written by Erin Gouveia Updated over 7 months ago  \nProject Navigator makes it easy to view, edit, and access all of the projects you're working on.¬†\n\n## Accessing Project Navigator\n \nTo access the Project Navigator, click the 'Project Navigator' page from the left panel of the app.¬†\n\n## Using Project Navigator\n \nIt will open a panel that shows a list of all the projects you have been added to in Hive. If you're looking for a particular project, you can search for it using the search bar.\n\nIf you want to see which projects you're a member of, you should go to My Projects tab. \n\nYou can see certain project information at a glance and control which columns (like the name of each project, the team members involved, the status, start and end dates, budget and project custom fields) are displayed for each project. Use the 'Manage columns' button on the right-hand side of Project Navigator to control these columns. You can also sort the columns to make it easier for you to navigate through your projects.\n\nIf you need to filter your projects by a project custom field value, this is something you can do as well. You need to hover over a custom field column and click the Filter icon. Set your value and you'll get a list of matching projects.\n\nWhen you hover over a specific project, four options appear on the right (Tip: you may have to scroll over if you have many project custom fields!)\n\n Edit **- Change the settings of your project\n \n‚Ä¢ \n**Copy** - Create another project with all the same tasks and layout with all dates removed\n \n‚Ä¢ \n**Archive** - Remove project from action panel while still maintaining the data in the \"Archived\" section of Project Navigator\n \n‚Ä¢ \n**Delete** - Remove the project and all its tasks from the workspace (Can be recovered from the Trash bin during 30 days).\n \nIn addition to your Active Projects and My Projects, you can also access your Archived Projects, Summary Views, and Templates from Project Navigator.\n\nTo quickly perform an update, you can also right-click on the project row in the Project Navigator. This will allow you to easily:\n \n‚Ä¢ \nOpen the project in a new tab\n \n‚Ä¢ \nPin project\n \n‚Ä¢ \nArchive project\n \n‚Ä¢ \nDelete project\n\n## Pinning projects\n \nIf you are working in certain projects or summary views frequently, you can pin those to the left-hand bar. ¬†By doing so, you'll be able to easily access those projects from anywhere within Hive.\n\nTo pin a project, simply click the pushpin icon to the left of the project name. Click it again if you'd like to remove it from the favorites section.¬†\n\n# More Menu\n \nIf you want to drill into a project without navigating away from whatever view you are on, you can use the More Menu. It allows you to:\n \n‚Ä¢ \nOpen a project in a new tab \n \n‚Ä¢ \nUnpin the project from your left sidebar\n \n‚Ä¢ \nArchive the project\n \n‚Ä¢ \nDelete the project.\n \nTo access it, simply hover over the desired app/project, right click on the three dots icon near the project, and choose the needed option. Voila! A separate tab in your browser will populate with the designated app/project. ‚Äã\n\n## Exporting Project Navigator\n \nIn case you need to report on all your projects (archived and active), you can export Project Navigator in CSV with all associated columns. \n\nTo export Project Navigator, select the \"Export\" button at the top right corner of your screen. All column information including project name, its members, status, start/due date, budget, and project custom fields will be included in the export. ‚Äã\n\nYou can manage the columns you wish to view in the export in the \"Manage columns\" dropdown next to the Export option.\n\nTo export archived projects, navigate to the Archived Projects tab and export the view.\n\n## Leaving Project Navigator\n \nIf you click one of the projects, it closes Project Navigator and opens up directly to the project. \n\n Related Articles Export project plans Project Baselines Import from Microsoft Project Hive 2.0 navigation Auto-generate Project IDs  üòû üòê üòÉ \n‚Ä¢ Sign In \n‚Ä¢ Forgot Password? \n‚Ä¢ API \n‚Ä¢ \n‚Ä¢",

          "content": "Notifications | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢ **     Using Hive Messaging & Communications Notifications \n# Notifications\n \nHow Hive provides updates on what's going on in your workspace\n Written by Erin Gouveia Updated over a year ago  \nWhether out on vacation or in a meeting, it's important to be able to easily catch up on what's happened while you were away.¬†\n\nHive notifications makes it easy to keep track of these critical changes.¬†\n\n To access your notifications, **click the bell in the upper right corner of the app.¬†\n\nIf you have something new to review, an orange dot will appear next to the bell.¬†\n \nHive notifications are divided into five categories:\n \n**Me** - Updates that are specific to you will live in the 'My notifications' tab. These are things such as new assignments, @ mentions, or direct chats.¬†\n \n‚Ä¢ \n**All **- Updates on actions you are following*\n \n‚Ä¢ \n**Mentions** - Updates on notifications where you were @ mentioned\n \n‚Ä¢ \n**Archived - **Notifications you archived\n \n‚Ä¢ \n**Pinned - **Notifications you pinned for a later use.\n \n*****You become a Follower of an action card (and therefore start receiving notifications on the card) if you:¬†\n \n‚Ä¢ \nCreate the card\n \n‚Ä¢ \nAre assigned to the card\n \n‚Ä¢ \nAre @ mentioned in the comment section\n \n‚Ä¢ \nComment on the card\n \nThe goal is to make it easier to find what you need. When you want to know about changes to work you are assigned to, check Me. If you want to check on work that you are following, then go to All.\n\nSee below for a breakdown of when a notification arrives in All, Me, Mentions, and Archived.\n\n# Reviewing your notifications\n \nWhen you see the orange dot appear on your notifications bell, click it to see what's happened in Hive.\n\n## Read and archive\n \nYou can mark a notification as read, just like you would an email, and return to it later.\n\nYou can also click each item to go to the specific action card or message it references. This way, you can use your notifications as a to-do list of items you need to take action on. \n\nOnce you're ready, you can click \"Archive\" to remove the notification from your list.\n\n## Bulk actions and unarchive\n \nHave a lot of notifications? Click \"Mark all as read\" to bulk read them. Then you can click \"Archive all\" to clear them from your list!\n\nTo go back and review an item you have already marked as read, click the \"Archived\" tab. You can select the \"mark as unread\" icon if you want to move it back to your notifications list.\n\n# Offline notifications\n \nWhen you are offline, notifications will also be pushed to your email and mobile in order for you to stay up to date with the latest changes. Your profile is moved to an 'offline' state when you exit out of the app or if you are inactive for 10 minutes.¬†\n\nTo manage your offline notification settings, go to your profile dropdown > Edit profile > Notification settings. Here you can toggle On/Off both email and mobile offline notifications.\n\nNote: this is also where you can manage banner notifications. Submitted forms have the option to automatically create an action card in Hive with all the form details. ‚Äã Some great uses for Hive forms can include:\n \ncollecting orders or requests\n \n‚Ä¢ \nsubmitting bugs and other issues\n \n‚Ä¢ \ngathering structuring information from employees (e.g. contact info)\n \n‚Ä¢ \ncapturing details for a new project request\n \n‚Ä¢ \nand much more!\n\n# How to create:\n \n‚Ä¢ \nEnable \"Forms\" from \"Hive Apps\" if it's not already enabled\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSelect \"Forms\"\n \n‚Ä¢ \nClick \"Create new form\" from the Forms Library page\n\n‚Ä¢ \nAdd a title and description\n \n‚Ä¢ \nDrag and drop the fields you want to add to the form\n \nThere are multiple different question type options and dynamic fields you can add to a Hive form. \n\nBelow are example questions that can be created using a Hive form:\n\n Checkbox Group¬† \n\n Date Field \n\n *Users can choose Min Date, Max Date/Min Date and Max Date to configure what dates a user can select from the form, this setting can be found in the edit modal for the Date Field in Forms. \n\n File Upload (can support any type of file) \n\n Header \n\n Paragraph \n\n Radio Group \n\n Text Field (Single or paragraph) \n\n Text Area \n\n Ruler \n\n Multi-text \n\nDepending on which field you choose, you have the option to make it required, add help text, set a max character length, and other customizations.\n \n‚Ä¢ \n Add confirmation message**\n \nThis is the message that the person will see after they submit the form.\n\n‚Ä¢ \n**Set where you want to submit the form¬†**\n\n# **Form Statuses **\n \nTo better control form versions and updates without losing prior submission data, we have three form statuses: **Draft, Published, and Archived.**\n\n‚Ä¢ \n**Draft** - This is where you work on designing, editing, or testing a form before it's ready for use.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nOnce you've made updates to your form or created a draft of it, selecting \"**Save**\" saves the form and maintains the ** Draft ** state. This means the edits you've made will ** not ** be published.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSelecting the \"**Publish**\" button saves the changes and allows the updated form to be displayed for members in the workspace.**‚Äã ‚Äã\n \n‚Ä¢ \nAll users can see a Draft Form in the Form Library, but it can only be published by the form owner or an Admin.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIf a member of your team opens a link to a Draft Form, they will get a message indicating this form is under construction and cannot be submitted.\n\n2. Published**\n \n‚Ä¢ \nOnce your form is ready to go live, selecting \"**Publish**\" will both** save and publish **the latest version of the form.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nAll members of your team can see published forms.\n\nCurious how to switch the form from Published back to Draft?**‚Äã\n \n As an Admin or form owner, ** you might decide the form needs modifications made in the Draft status. To unpublish the form, navigate to the three dots menu at the top of the screen to Mark it as draft.\n\n3. **Archived**\n \n‚Ä¢ \nArchive/Unarchive options in the form are only available for form owner and Admins. \n \n‚Ä¢ \nIf a member of your team opens a link to the Archived Form, they will get the same message as above indicating the form is unavailable.\n\n# **Pinning your Form: Individually vs Workspace pinning****\n \nThis allows quick access to forms you use on a day-to-day basis or find yourself frequently using. \n \n If everyone in the workspace does not have the same go-to forms, you can pin a form for yourself only **in your Personal Form Library. Here is some information on how the form's draft works!\n \n‚Ä¢ \nAny fields filled out in a form are saved automatically when you close the form.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nWhen you re-open the form in the same browser on the same device, the answers you had previously filled out will still be there.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nAttachments will not ** be saved, so if you re-enter the form, the attachment will need to be uploaded again.\n \n# Duplicating Form Questions\n \nUsers will be able to duplicate the question in the form by clicking on the Duplicate button in the Form Editor!\n \n‚Ä¢ \nAny Logic that was placed in the question will carry over.\n\n# Enable/disable holidays & weekends\n \nIf you'd like to allow your users to select weekends / holidays when submitting the form or instead, limit them from doing so, you'll use the following guidance:\n \n‚Ä¢ \nWhen editing the form, click on your Date question > Data section > Ensure the setting to \"Include holidays\"/ \"Include weekends\" is checked.\n\n‚Ä¢ \n\na) If your form is creating an action card in a specific project, go to your project settings and ensure the option to \"Allow actions to be assigned on weekends\" is checked.\n \n Note: If your form is creating a project using a project template, you'll check this setting in your project template settings. \n\nb) If your form is creating an action without a project or an entirely new project, you'll go to your Workspace Settings > Project default settings > check the option to \"Allow actions to be assigned on weekends\".\n\n# **Custom Logo for each form**\n \nTo upload a custom logo for each form, use the External Logo option in the General settings.           "content": "Starting & Stopping Recipes | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢ **     Hive Automate Recipe Management Starting & Stopping Recipes \n# Starting & Stopping Recipes\n Written by Michaela Rollings Updated over 3 years ago  \nYou can work with recipes in various ways:\n \ntest a recipe to run a single trigger event through the recipe logic\n \n‚Ä¢ \nstart a recipe to have it pick up trigger events\n \n‚Ä¢ \nstop a recipe to have it stop processing new trigger events\n \n‚Ä¢ \nuse skip step to build and test your recipes incrementally\n \nDuring recipe development, we recommend building and testing in small chunks. To enter test mode, click Test jobs** or the **Test** button in the top right corner of the Recipe editor.\n\n# **Starting Recipes**\n \nStarting a recipe will cause it to pick up trigger events and process them through the recipe. When a recipe is started, it becomes **active**.\n\nStarting a recipe with a real-time trigger (like those in the Hive connector) will result in the recipe immediately listening for the specified events, with the specified trigger conditions. It will keep fetching events until the recipe is stopped.\n\nWhen a recipe with trigger time intervals is first started, it will fetch trigger events from the 'when first started, this recipe should pick up events from' configuration. Subsequently, it will continuously process these events. If you had defined the **Since/From** date during testing previously, this date cannot be changed again for this recipe\n \n## \n\n# **Stopping Recipes**\n \nStopping a recipe makes it **inactive**. It will stop picking up trigger events. Recipes have to be stopped to make changes to the recipe, or to rename the recipe.\n\nReal-time triggers powered by webhooks (like those in the Hive connector) will trigger events that occur during the time that the recipe is running. If the recipe was stopped triggers will not be picked up by the recipe during the time of inactivity.\n\nRecipes with trigger intervals will continue where they have left off when a recipe is restarted from a stopped state. For example, if it was stopped on Monday, and started again from Thursday, the recipe will fetch all trigger events since Monday and process them.\n\n ‚Äã\n Related Articles What is Hive Automate?
