          "content": "How to Automate a Goal | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢     Product Updates How to Automate a Goal \n# How to Automate a Goal\n Written by Erin Gouveia Updated over 12 months ago  \nWith Hive's new Goals feature, not only can you create Goals that update based on Hive activities, but you can also hook up your existing business tools to directly update your Goal progress in Hive. Here are a few use cases we're excited about that are now possible with Hive Automate + Goals: \n\n## If your Goal is Driven by Revenue\n \nWe can connect to your CRM, like Salesforce or Hubspot, or your billing platform, to allow you to automatically update your Goal's current value for metrics like:\n \n$ Target for ARR in Q1\n \n‚Ä¢ \n$ Target for Pipeline created\n \n‚Ä¢ \n$ Target for Closed Won Business in a specific month or quarter\n \n‚Ä¢ \n% of monthly churn in your customer base\n\n## If your Goal is Driven by Lead Volume\n \nSimilarly, we can connect to Hubspot or many other Marketing Automation tools to gather the current number of leads, or leads created over a given period. Measure Goals like: ‚Äã\n \n‚Ä¢ \nTotal Leads Created This Month\n \n‚Ä¢ \nLeads Converted This Quarter\n\n## If your Goal is Driven by Customer Sentiment\n \nMeasure and track your NPS, or other customer survey scores by connecting them directly into your Goals. If you're customer-centric, this is a must! Goals like:\n \n‚Ä¢ \nOverall NPS this Year\n \n‚Ä¢ \nNPS in a Given Quarter\n\nüí™ We're just getting started - let us know which tools power your Goals, and we'll work to add support for it. \n\n# Updating your Goal using Hive Automate\n \nUtilize the Hive Automate feature to automatically update your Goal in Hive. In this example, we will demonstrate how to add a numerical value to your current Goal using a custom field in an action card, triggered upon the completion of the action card.\n\nIn this example, we will update our ARR goal by adding the value of the custom field to our overall Goal whenever an action card is completed in a specific project.\n\n1. Create a Goal that tracks numerical value.\n\n2. Create a Custom Field that captures the value of the account.\n \n 3. Create a Hive Automate recipe.\n \n4. Make a Hive Connection in Hive Automate. 5. Set up the recipe to capture when an action card is completed.\n\n6. Retrieve action card information by using the ID.\n \n ‚Äã\n \n7. Create a Variable in Hive Automate to capture the custom field value.\n \n a. [Custom Field datapill] is getting all of the custom field in that action card \n \n b. .where(\"id\":\"CUSTOM_FIELD_ID\") is grabbing the specific ID of the custom field \n \n If you need help getting the ID of your custom field, please reference our Get Custom Field ID documentation . \n \n c. .pluck('numberValue') is specifically grabbing the integer value of the custom field \n \n d. .join is converting the value from C and converting it from Array to String \n \n e. .to_i is converting the value from D and converting it from String to Integer \n\n8. Retrieve the details of a Goal. ‚Äã\n\n9. Create another Variable in Hive Automate that captures the Goal value.\n\n10. Use the Update Goal step to update the value of the Goal with the Action Card Custom Field.\n\nUpon completing an action card, the custom field value associated with the action card will be automatically added to the Goal value.\n\nPlease refer to the attached GIF for a visual demonstration. As you can observe, the Goal initially displayed a value of $46,000. However, upon completing the action card, the value increased to $56,000.           "content": "# Formulas: Lists\n Written by Michaela Rollings Updated over 3 years ago  \nIn addition to the basic data types (for example, string and integer), you may encounter more complex data structures that contain information about multiple items or multiple pieces of information about a single item. You may encounter Lists, Hashes, or Lists of Hashes. Formulas in Hive Automate are whitelisted Ruby methods, and therefore not all Ruby methods are supported.\n\nYou can refer to the syntax and sample uses of these commands by clicking the links below: \n \n Lists (arrays) \n \n Hashes \n \n Lists of hashes \n \n Example list of hashes \n \n first \n \n last \n \n index \n \n where \n \n except \n \n pluck \n \n format_map \n \n join \n \n smart_join \n \n reverse \n \n sum \n \n uniq \n \n flatten \n \n length \n \n max \n \n min \n \n compact \n \n blank? \n \n include? \n \n present? \n \n presence \n \n to_csv \n \n to_json \n \n to_xml \n \n from_xml \n \n encode_www_form \n \n to_param \n \n keys \n\n# Lists (arrays)**\n \nArrays are ordered, integer-indexed collections of any object. List indexing starts at 0. Lists and arrays refer to the same data structure.\n \nIn the example below, a list of integers is expressed as:\n \nnumber_list = [100, 101, 102, 103, 104] As lists are ordered, we can use the following formula to get the values. Hive Automate only supports retrieving up to the fifth item using this syntax.\n \n**Formula**\n \n**Result**\n \nnumber_list.first\n \n100\n \nnumber_list.second\n \n101\n \nnumber_list.third\n \n102\n \nnumber_list.fourth\n \n103\n \nnumber_list.fifth\n \n104\n \nnumber_list.last\n \n104\n \nWe can also use indexes to get corresponding values. Remember, indexes start at 0:\n \n**Formula**\n \n**Result**\n \nnumber_list[0]\n \n100\n \nnumber_list[1]\n \n101\n \nnumber_list[2]\n \n102\n \nnumber_list[3]\n \n103\n \nLists in Ruby supports negative indexes.\n \n**Formula**\n \n**Result**\n \nnumber_list[-1]\n \n104\n \nnumber_list[-2]\n \n103\n \nnumber_list[-3]\n \n102\n \nnumber_list[-4]\n \n101\n \nLists also support ranges as indexes. This returns another list, instead of returning only a value.\n \n**Formula**\n \n**Result**\n \nnumber_list[0..2]\n \n[100, 101, 102]\n \nnumber_list[-3..-1]\n \n[102, 103, 104]\n \nnumber_list[0..-2]\n \n[100, 101, 102, 103]\n\n# **Hashes**\n \nA hash is a dictionary-like collection of unique keys and their values. They are similar to Lists, but where a List uses integers as its index, a Hash allows you to use any object type. Hashes enumerate their values in the order that the corresponding keys were inserted.\n \nLet's take the example of a hash with 2 values, with 'Acme widgets' and 10 as the values of item_name and item_quantity respectively.\n\nline_item = { 'item_name' => 'Acme widgets', 'item_qty' => 10 } **Formula**\n \n**Result**\n \nline_item[\"item_name\"]\n \n\"Acme widgets\"\n \nline_item[\"item_qty\"]\n \n10\n\n# **Lists of hashes**\n \nHere is an example of an invoice which has multiple line items. It is represented as a list of hashes.\n \nline_items = [ { 'item_no': 1, 'item_name' => 'Acme widgets', 'item_qty' => 10 }, { 'item_no': 2, 'item_name' => 'RR bearings', 'item_qty' => 99 }, { 'item_no': 3, 'item_name' => 'Coyote tyres', 'item_qty' => 7 } ] \n \n# \n \n# **Example list of hashes**\n \nThe following is an example of a list of hashes called **Contacts**.\n \nThis is the Contacts list in a table form:\n \n**name**\n \n**email**\n \n**state**\n \n**company**\n \n**company_rev**\n \nJoe\n \n joe@abc.com \n \nCA\n \nABC\n \n1000\n \nJill\n \n jill@nbc.com \n \nMA\n \nNBC\n \n1000\n \nJoan\n \n joan@nbc.com \n \nMA\n \nNBC\n \n10000\n \nJack\n \n jack@hbo.com \n \nCA\n \nHBO\n \n30000\n \nThis is the Contacts list in a list of hashes form.\n \n[ **{ 'name' => 'Joe', 'email' => 'joe@abc.com', 'state' => 'CA', 'company' => 'ABC', 'company_rev' => 1000, 'description' => { 'summary' => 'First time buyer', 'estimated_value' => 300 } }, { 'name' => 'Jill', 'email' => 'jill@nbc.com', 'state' => 'MA', 'company' => 'NBC', 'company_rev' => 1000, 'description' => { 'summary' => 'Referral', 'estimated_value' => 500 } }, { 'name' => 'Joan', 'email' => 'joan@nbc.com', 'state' => 'MA', 'company' => 'NBC', 'company_rev' => 10000, 'description' => { 'summary' => 'Recurring customer', 'estimated_value' => 900 } }, { 'name' => 'Jack', 'email' => 'jack@hbo.com', 'state' => 'CA', 'company' => 'HBO', 'company_rev' => 30000, 'description' => { 'summary' => 'Recurring customer', 'estimated_value' => 1000 } } ] \n\n# first**\n \nThis formula returns the first item in a list.\n \nIt can also be used to return the first n items in a list. In this case, the output will be formatted as a list.\n\n## Syntax\n \nList.first(number)\n \nList - An input list.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nnumber - (optional) The number of items to retrieve from the list. If not specified, the formula will return only one item.\n \n## Sample usage\n \n**Formula**\n \n**Result**\n \n[\"One\",\"Two\",\"Three\",\"Four\",\"Five\"].first()\n \n\"One\"\n \n[\"One\",\"Two\",\"Three\",\"Four\",\"Five\"].first(2)\n \n[\"One\",\"Two\"]\n \n[1,2,3,4,5].first()\n \n1\n \n[1,2,3,4,5].first(3)\n \n[1,2,3]\n \n## How it works\n \nThis formula returns the first n items from a list. If n is greater than one, the output is formatted as a list.\n\n# **last**\n \nThis formula returns the last item in a list.\n \nIt can also be used to return the last n items in a list. In this case, the output will be formatted as a list.\n\n## Syntax\n \nList.last(number)\n \n‚Ä¢ \nList - An input list.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nnumber - (optional) The number of items to retrieve from the list. If not specified, the formula will return only one item.\n \n## Sample usage\n \n**Formula**\n \n**Result**\n \n[\"One\",\"Two\",\"Three\",\"Four\",\"Five\"].last()\n \n\"Five\"\n \n[\"One\",\"Two\",\"Three\",\"Four\",\"Five\"].last(2)\n \n[\"Four\",\"Five\"]\n \n[1,2,3,4,5].last()\n \n5\n \n[1,2,3,4,5].last(3)\n \n[3,4,5]\n \n## How it works\n \nThis formula returns the last n items from a list. If n is greater than one, the output is formatted as a list.\n\n# **index**\n \nReturns the index of the first item matching the given value. Returns nil if no matching items are found.\n\n## Syntax\n \nInput.index(value)\n \n‚Ä¢ \nInput - An input list.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nvalue - The value to search for in the list.\n \n## Sample usage\n \n**Formula**\n \n**Result**\n \n[4, 5, 6, 7].index(6)\n \n2\n \n[4, 5, 6, 7].index(8)\n \nnil\n\n# **where**\n \nRetrieves only the rows (hashes) which satisfy the specified WHERE condition. This formula accepts a single argument in the form of a hash with one or more key-value pairs.\n \nThe default operand for the condition is **equal to** ( == ). This formula also supports the following operands. Operands should be added to the end of key separated by a space.\n \n**Name**\n \n**Notation**\n \n**Example**\n \nEqual to (default)\n \n==\n \nleads.where('state': 'CA')\n \nMore than\n \n>\n \nleads.where('company_revenue >\": 10000)\n \nMore than or equal to\n \n>=\n \nleads.where('company_revenue >=\": 10000)\n \nLess than\n \n<\n \nleads.where('company_revenue <\": 10000)\n \nLess than or equal to\n \n<=\n \nleads.where('company_revenue <=\": 10000)\n \nNot equal to\n \n!=\n \nleads.where('state !=': 'CA')\n \n**Example of a single where condition**\n \n contacts.where('state': 'CA') returns the following rows:\n \n**name**\n \n**email**\n \n**state**\n \n**company**\n \n**company_rev**\n \nJoe\n \n joe@abc.om \n \nCA\n \nABC\n \n1000\n \nJack\n \n jack@hbo.com \n \nCA\n \nHBO\n \n30000\n \nThese rows will be expressed as a list of hashes:\n \n[ **{ 'name' => 'Joe', 'email' => 'joe@abc.com', 'state' => 'CA', 'company' => 'ABC', 'company_rev' => 1000 }, { 'name' => 'Jack', 'email' => 'jack@hbo.com', 'state' => 'CA', 'company' => 'HBO', 'company_rev' => 30000 } ] \n \n Example of a compound where formula**\n \nA compound WHERE formula will retrieve only the rows that matches all the conditions.\n \n contacts.where('state': 'CA', 'company_revenue >=\": 10000) \n \nwill returns the following rows:\n \n**name**\n \n**email**\n \n**state**\n \n**company**\n \n**company_rev**\n \nJack\n \n jack@hbo.com \n \nCA\n \nHBO\n \n30000\n \nThese rows will be expressed as a list of hashes:\n \n[ **{ 'name' => 'Jack', 'email' => 'jack@hbo.com', 'state' => 'CA', 'company' => 'HBO', 'company_rev' => 30000 } ] \n \n Example of multiple matches**\n \nYou can filter out records based on a particular field against more than 1 value. This is done by passing an array value in the WHERE condition.\n \n contacts.where('company': ['ABC','HBO']) \n \nThis WHERE condition will return rows where the company is either **ABC** or **HBO**:\n \n**name**\n \n**email**\n \n**state**\n \n**company**\n \n**company_rev**\n \nJoe\n \n joe@abc.om \n \nCA\n \nABC\n \n1000\n \nJack\n \n jack@hbo.com \n \nCA\n \nHBO\n \n30000\n \nThese rows will be returned as a list of hashes.\n \n[ **{ 'name' => 'Joe', 'email' => 'joe@abc.com', 'state' => 'CA', 'company' => 'ABC', 'company_rev' => 1000 }, { 'name' => 'Jack', 'email' => 'jack@hbo.com', 'state' => 'CA', 'company' => 'HBO', 'company_rev' => 30000 } ] \n \n Example where condition with pattern matching**\n \nYou can also filter out records using regex. This is done by passing a regex instead of a string.\n \n contacts.where('name': /^Jo/) \n \nThis WHERE condition will return rows where the name starts with **Jo**:\n \n**name**\n \n**email**\n \n**state**\n \n**company**\n \n**company_rev**\n \nJoe\n \n joe@abc.om \n \nCA\n \nABC\n \n1000\n \nJoan\n \n joan@nbc.com \n \nMA\n \nNBC\n \n10000\n \nThese rows will be expressed as a list of hashes:\n \n[ **{ 'name' => 'Joe', 'email' => 'joe@abc.com', 'state' => 'CA', 'company' => 'ABC', 'company_rev' => 1000 }, { 'name' => 'Joan', 'email' => 'joan@nbc.com', 'state' => 'MA', 'company' => 'NBC', 'company_rev' => 10000 } ] \n \n Example where condition with pattern matching (using datapills)**\n \nYou may use data pills within a regex pattern to dynamically change the string that you are matching. However, using variables in a regex pattern requires escaping within the regex expression.\n \nFor example: contacts.where(state: /#{ datapill }/)\n \nThe image below shows the method used to obtain all the 'Emails' in lookup table where the value in the 'State' column contains the string in the datapill from Salesforce, State | Step 2 .\n\n**Note:** All regex metacharacters will need to be escaped if they should not be interpreted as metacharacters.\n\n**Example of chaining where conditions**\n \nIf a series of WHERE conditions are chained, the formula evaluates each where condition in series.\n \n contacts.where('state': 'CA').where('company_revenue >=': 10000) returns the following rows, which is the same as the compound where formula:\n \n**name**\n \n**email**\n \n**state**\n \n**company**\n \n**company_rev**\n \nJack\n \n jack@hbo.com \n \nCA\n \nHBO\n \n30000\n \nIn this case, however, the chaining will result in an intermediary array:\n \n contacts.where('state': 'CA') first returns:\n \n**name**\n \n**email**\n \n**state**\n \n**company**\n \n**company_rev**\n \nJoe\n \n joe@abc.om \n \nCA\n \nABC\n \n1000\n \nJack\n \n jack@hbo.com \n \nCA\n \nHBO\n \n30000\n \nAnd .where('company_revenue >=': 10000) filters this intermediary array further to return only:\n \n**name**\n \n**email**\n \n**state**\n \n**company**\n \n**company_rev**\n \nJack\n \n jack@hbo.com \n \nCA\n \nHBO\n \n30000\n \nResults will be expressed as a list of hashes:\n \n[ **{ 'name' => 'Jack', 'email' => 'jack@hbo.com', 'state' => 'CA', 'company' => 'HBO', 'company_rev' => '30000' } ] \n\n# except**\n \nReturns a hash that includes everything except given keys.\n \nhash = { a: true, b: false, c: nil } **hash.except(:c) # => { a: true, b: false } hash.except(:a, :b) # => { c: nil } hash # => { a: true, b: false, c: nil } \n\n# pluck**\n \n Retrieves only the columns which have been specified.\n\n## Sample usage\n\n**Example of a single column dataput**\n \n contacts.pluck(\"email\") returns\n \n**email**\n \n joe@abc.com \n \n jill@nbc.com \n \n joan@nbc.com \n \n jack@hbo.com \n \nIf a single column, results will be returned as an array:\n \n[\"joe@abc.com\", \"jill@nbc.com\", \"joan@nbc.com\", \"jack@hbo.com\"] \n \n**Example of a multiple column dataset**\n \n contacts.where(\"state ==\": \"CA\").pluck(\"email\", \"company\") returns\n \n**email**\n \n**company**\n \n joe@abc.com \n \nABC\n \n jill@nbc.com \n \nNBC\n \n joan@nbc.com \n \nNBC\n \n jack@hbo.com \n \nHBO\n \nResults are returned as a list of a list:\n \n[[\"joe@abc.com\", \"ABC\"], [\"jill@nbc.com\", \"NBC\"], [\"joan@nbc.com\", \"NBC\"], [\"jack@hbo.com\", \"HBO\"]] \n \n**Example of retrieving nested fields**\n \nThis method can be used to extract nested fields. Use the [<1st-level field>,<2nd-level field>...] format to define which fields to retrieve.\n \n contacts.pluck(\"email\", [\"description\", \"summary\"]) returns\n \n**email**\n \n**summary**\n \n joe@abc.com \n \nFirst time buyer\n \n jill@nbc.com \n \nReferral\n \n joan@nbc.com \n \nRecurring customer\n \n jack@hbo.com \n \nRecurring customer\n \nResults are returned as a list of lists:\n \n[ [\"joe@abc.com\", \"First time buyer\"], [\"jill@nbc.com\", \"Referral\"], [\"joan@nbc.com\", \"Recurring customer\"], [\"jack@hbo.com\", \"Recurring customer\"] ] \n\n# **format_map**\n \nCreate an array of strings by formatting each row of given array of hashes. Allows you to add static text to the created strings as well. Fields to be represented in the format %{**<field_name>**}.\n\n## Sample usage\n \n contacts.format_map('Name: %{name}, Email: %{email}, Company: %{company}') \n\nreturns\n\n[ **'Name: Joe, Email: joe@abc.com, Company: ABC' , 'Name: Jill, Email: jill@nbc.com, Company: NBC' , 'Name: Joan, Email: joan@nbc.com, Company: NBC' , 'Name: Jack, Email: jack@hbo.com, Company: HBO' , ] The preceding example will give you a list of strings, one string for each row of the list \"contacts\"**, using data from 3 of the fields: name, email, and company, as stated.\n\n# **join**\n \nCombines all items in a list into a text string. A separator is placed between each item.\n\n## Syntax\n \nList.join(separator)\n \n‚Ä¢ \nList - An input of list datatype.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nseparator - The character to add between items when they are joined.           "content": "Formula Custom Fields | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢ **     Using Hive Custom Fields Formula Custom Fields \n# Formula Custom Fields\n \nDynamically calculate custom fields\n A Written by Alexander Heldring Updated over 3 years ago  \nFormula custom fields allow you to create relationships between custom fields using simple or advanced formulas. \n\nFor example, if you have two existing custom fields ('Cost per person' and 'Number of people') you could create a formula custom field ('Total cost') to multiply their values. \n\nFormula custom fields are available for both project and action custom fields.           "content": "Project templates | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢ **     Using Hive Projects Project templates \n# Project templates\n \nCreate and apply templates to projects to quickly get work kicked off\n Written by Erin Gouveia Updated over 5 months ago  \nApplying a project template to a new or existing project allows you to easily bring in a set of actions with pre-specified assignees, due dates and information. attributes to your template (name, dates, color)\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSelect who you'd like to share the template with¬†\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSelect the default layout for the template\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSelect 'Create Template'\n labels, etc.)\n\n## **How to apply a template to a new project**\n \n‚Ä¢ \nFind the desired template in the 'Templates' tab\n \n‚Ä¢ \nHover over the template and select 'Apply'\n \n‚Ä¢ \nName the project¬†\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSelect start and/or end dates of the project, if desired (this will map template actions that have start and due dates to the new project)\n \n‚Ä¢ \nUpdate project settings, as desired (Make sure to select to copy assignees of actions if you would like template assignees to carry over in the new project)\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSelect 'Apply template'\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSee the new project in the 'Active Projects' tab in Project Navigator\n\nProject sections, actions and subactions (and associated assignees, start and due dates and labels) from the template will be visible in the new project and can then be edited and updated in the project settings for the needs of the new project.\n\n## **How to apply a template to an existing project**\n \n‚Ä¢ \nGo to the more menu within the project\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSelect 'Apply project template'\n \n‚Ä¢ \nChoose a template from the list (this list pulls from Active Projects and Templates in project navigator, so you have the option to choose from either list)\n \n‚Ä¢ \nApply project template and see your actions populate!\n\n## **How to convert an existing project to a template¬†**\n \nIf you have existing projects that you want to use as templates, you can easily convert them into a template and move them to the 'Templates' tab.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nOpen your project\n \n‚Ä¢ \nGo to the more menu within your project\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSelect 'Save as template'\n           "content": "Optimize Your Project Templates | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢ **     Using Hive Projects Optimize Your Project Templates \n# Optimize Your Project Templates\n Written by Andrew Naisawald Updated over 4 months ago  \nWant to make sure that your Project Templates are optimized and ready for the most efficient use?\n\nRefer to the below checklist to make sure that your Project Templates contain all of the following components:\n\n## 1. Ensure your Project Template has a Project Start/Due Date**\n \nCheck that your template has a project start and/or due date. This acts as a link between your project template and any new projects created from this template to ensure that action durations and dependencies transfer over to the new project properly.\n\n**Pro-tip**: Ensure your **new** project also has a project start and/or due date at creation. If your template has a project start/due date, then when creating a new project from the template the project start/due date will automatically be populated for the new project.\n\n## **2. Assign actions to Placeholders**\n \nAssign the actions in your template to Placeholders . Using Placeholders in your template will allow for efficient updates to the actual resources that will be working on those actions in your project. \n\nBefore you can assign actions to Placeholders, check the Template Project Settings page to make sure Placeholders have been added to the Template. Once added to the Template, then Placeholders can be assigned to actions.\n\n## **3. Add durations and dependencies to your actions**\n \nWhile not required, ensuring that the action cards in the Project Template have relative due dates, durations, and dependencies is a best practice for optimizing Project Templates. \n\nWhile you may not know the exact duration for every action in your project, it is still recommended to add approximate start and end dates for each action. That way when applying the template, each action has a starting point to work from when shaping the project plan for the new project.\n\n## **4. Manage Labels and Apply them to Necessary Action Cards**\n \n Labels are a great way to manage key initiatives or categorize certain actions for designated teams. \n\nProject Templates can be pre-set to not only limit which labels are available in the project, but also to have labels pre-applied on action cards. That way when the template is applied for a new project, the action cards in the project come pre-set with their applicable labels helping to maintain project consistency and completeness.\n\n## 5. Grant access to the Project Template to Hive Teams\n \nIn addition to making sure members of a Hive Team have access to a template, members of the Project Template are listed by default in the Project Membership section when new projects are created using the template.\n\nAdditionally, inviting Teams rather than individuals to templates helps to ensure template membership is kept up to date as team membership changes. New members added to a Hive Team will automatically be granted access to templates and projects where the Hive Team is a member.\n\n## **6. Review your Project Settings**\n \nWhen a project template is used to create a new project, the template's project setting will apply as the default settings for the new project. Therefore, it is important to check that the project and auto-scheduling settings on the project template are appropriate.\n\nIn the project Permission settings, you can define who can edit, apply, and access\n \nthe project template.\n\nPro-tip: In your Workspace Settings, you can also select the project template you'd like to be automatically applied by default each time a new project is created.\n\nChecking that your Project Templates have the above items will set them up for success!\n\n Related Articles Action templates Project templates Adding placeholder resources to projects Run a modern agency on Hive New This Week in Hive: August 2021  üòû üòê üòÉ Sign In \n‚Ä¢ Forgot Password? \n‚Ä¢ API \n‚Ä¢ \n‚Ä¢",

          "content": "Gantt charts | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢ **     Using Hive Projects Gantt charts \n# Gantt charts\n \nThe easiest way to plan your project\n A Written by Alexander Heldring Updated over 5 months ago  \nGantt charts have been around for a long time - what was missing was the ability to actually use** the Gantt chart to execute your project.\n\nWith Gantt charts, Hive allows you to **plan** and **execute** your project, all in the same tool. You can zoom in to look a few weeks or zoom out to look at a project over a whole year.\n\n## Going fullscreen\n \nIf you want to make your Gantt view bigger, you can expand it to cover your whole screen.\n\n## Changing assignees\n \n## \n \n## Marking complete\n\n## Hiding subactions\n\n## Add dates\n \nThere are different ways to add dates to your actions in Gantt view! You can click on the needed cell on the timeline or use our Gantt Table to select dates from the date picker.\n\nPro-tip: to easily update multiple actions with a new date, you can simply copy the date cell on Gantt Table and paste it into the needed one.\n\n## Add Dependencies \n \nClick circle and drag to the beginning of the next action\n\n## Expand your Actions\n \nCheck out the counter and expand/collapse each layer of your subactions. Use additional options in the dropdown to Expand all or Collapse all.\n\n## Wrapping Column Text\n \nRight-click on the title of the action card then choose the \"Wrap column text\".\n \nThis will make the text wrap around in the column.\n\n## Add colors\n \nTo make your Gantt more customizable and visually appealing, as well as create better organization, you can change the color of action card bars.\n\nTo do that, right-click the desired action and select a color. The color will automatically override any label colors from actions, and apply to all project views and summary views. \n\n## Displaying Percentage Completion\n \nIf you wish to display the percentage completion of your parent action card by its subactions, you can enable the ‚ÄúDisplay percent complete‚Äù option in the Configure settings.\n\nYou can also set this percentage completion manually by changing the \"Display percent complete\" to \"Manually Update\", and then drag the icon to change the percentage.\n\n## Hide/show elements\n \nNavigate to Filters to customize your view and hide or show elements such as milestones, actions, and sections. The \"Show\" dropdown under the Display section will allow you to better visualize independent goals within Gantt. ‚Äã\n\n## Highlight changes\n \nWhen a date is changed, you'll see Hive highlighting action start/due dates that were changed as well.\n\nThis makes it easier for your team ‚Äî specifically project managers ‚Äî to run \"What if\" scenarios in Gantt before taking action. ‚Äã The highlight will disappear when you change a new date or leave the project & come back in.\n\n## Select multiple actions in Gantt\n \nIn Gantt, you can hover over the action row to find the checkbox, which will help bulk-select action cards and update multiple automatically.\n\n Another way is holding Shift to select all actions in between!\n\n## Settings\n \nYou can also customize your Gantt view and enable or disable different columns based on your needs.           "content": "New App: Goals | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢   Table of contents  Using Hive New App: Goals \n# New App: Goals\n \nTrack your progress easily\n Written by Michaela Rollings Updated over 9 months ago Table of contents \n\nIf you're looking for an easy way to track progress toward your goals, the Goals app is what you need. To use it, you have to turn it on in your Apps first.\n\n# Creating your goal\n \nAfter turning on the app, you'll be able to create your first goal. You can add such details as Name of your Goal, Owner, Time range, and Goal measurement.\n\n It's possible to measure your goal based on Actions completed (automatic tracking based on action card completion) or Number (manual tracking and updating your goal).\n\nIf you want to track your goal based on completed or overdue actions, you'll get an option to choose either or individual actions as your progress source. From there, you'll be able to select your projects/actions as well as the parent goal if applicable (this new goal will be added as a sub-goal). If you go for 'Selected Actions', you'll see the checkbox to include subactions too. Lastly, you can display your goal as a Progress Bar (shows the percentage of completion) or Current Value (shows the current number of completed actions). \n\nIf you'd like to track your progress manually instead, you can select Number under Goal measurement and then add your Unit of measurement. Available options include Percentage, Currency, or your custom unit. Then you'll get to enter Initial value, Current value, and Goal value. You can also select your parent goal and choose the display type. \n\n# Viewing details and making edits\n \nAfter creating your goal, click on it to see all the details and add or edit things like description, subgoals, projects, and more. Please keep in mind that if your goal is tracked based on completed actions, incomplete actions will always show up at the top. \n\nYou can also change the status of your goal.           "content": "Portfolio View | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢ **   Table of contents  Using Hive Reporting & Dashboard Views Portfolio View \n# Portfolio View\n \nA bird's eye view of your entire business\n Written by Erin Gouveia Updated over a year ago Table of contents \nPortfolio View is the all-in-one place to see the detail of Project Navigator combined with the flexibility of a Table View. Once you click on that, you will end up in a space like this: \n\n## Components of Portfolio View: Projects, Details & Actions\n \nYou can build a Portfolio view your way, including these 3 building blocks:\n \nThe \"Projects\" dropdown will allow you to select which projects you'd like to see. You can click 'Select all' to have all of your projects added if that's what you need. \n \n‚Ä¢ \nThe dropdown for \"Project Fields\" allows you to pull in project fields and custom fields.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nThe dropdown that says \"Actions\" allows you to pull in the status of the actions and subactions that are living across projects listed on the left. Within the \"Actions\" dropdown, you can decide if you want to see specific milestones, too!\n \nIn the below example, we have four project fields pulling in: Status, Description, Project due date, and Project Owner. Status and Description fields can be edited directly from this view - simply double click on the cell next to the needed project! ‚Äã\n \n Other fields can be edited within the \"Overview\" button of a project. Just click on the project in the table and click \"Overview\" toward the top right.\n\nActions pulled into the portfolio view will show a due date if they're incomplete, a green check if they're complete, or \"N/A\" if the action card doesn't exist yet in one of the selected projects. \n\nMilestone actions pulled into Portfolio View will show the date they are due along with the flag icon to indicate that it has been set as a milestone in the project. If an action is set as a milestone in one project, but the same action lives in another and it's not set as a milestone, the difference will be the flag icon beside the date to show where it's a milestone. \n\n## Create, Save & Share:\n \nIf you manage more than one portfolio, and would like quicker access to it, now you can save the view.\n\nTo do so, click the Title of the Portfolio View and create a new one. Now both are available in your drop down!\n\nTo share a view with others, head to the Menu > Share icon on the right:\n\nAnd add your teammates:\n\n### Share a read-only public link to your Portfolio view\n \nWhen Access type is set to 'Anyone with a link', you can copy the share link to your Portfolio view and send it to your stakeholders.\n\nTo share a public link to a filtered Portfolio view, Workspace Admins and Portfolio owner ** can use the 'Lock editing' button at the top of the screen. \n\nWhen enabled, only Workspace Admins and Portfolio owner can filter in the Portfolio View.\n\n**Note:** The Global icon on your Portfolio view means that the view is shared publicly and any filter changes you make will be reflected in the public view as well.\n\nPortfolio View is best leveraged when looking at multiple projects that have the same action cards and/or custom fields because you can then compare those projects accurately and efficiently. \n\n## How to remove a project from Portfolio View\n \nTo remove a project from a portfolio view, you can select the project and toggle off the button next to the project title.\n\n There's more to discover with Portfolio View, so check out this related post: https://hive.com/blog/portfolio-view/ \n\n Related Articles Gantt charts Plan & execute company initiatives Run a modern agency on Hive List View: A New Project View in Hive Home View: List View (New)!  üòû üòê üòÉ \n‚Ä¢ Sign In \n‚Ä¢ Forgot Password? \n‚Ä¢ API \n‚Ä¢ \n‚Ä¢",

It's easy to invite them.\n A Written by Alexander Heldring Updated over 11 months ago  \nTo get the most out of Hive, bring your entire team into your workspace.¬†\n\n From the top right, select 'Invite' button:**\n\nFor full access users , use the 'New teammate' option (which is the default) as shown above. For External Users , use the External user option just to the right. \n \n‚Ä¢ \nEnter the email of the people you want to add\n \n‚Ä¢ \nClick 'Next' and select which projects these users should have access to, and which teams they should be members of. \n \n‚Ä¢ \nYou have the option of including a note in the invite email, or, uncheck the box to notify the user to NOT send them a notification about their invite\n \n‚Ä¢ \nClick 'Send Invite'.\n \nSee the flow illustrated here!\n\n**Tip:** If you are looking to invite someone as an External User , make sure to use the External User tab as highlighted below. Otherwise, they will be added as a full workspace member and a charge to your subscription. \n\nIt's also possible to invite new users directly from the people picker. You'll see the prompt to invite a new user when entering their email address. Once you confirm you want to invite them to your workspace, an invite will be generated and sent to their email. \n\n **‚Äã\n \n## Request to invite a user from an Admin‚Äã\n\nWorkspace Admins will be able to approve or deny these requests from the \"Pending Approval\" tab.\n\n ‚Äã \n \n# FAQ**\n \n Q: If I added someone as an **external** user and want to make them a **full access **workspace member, what do I do? \n\nA: Go to Manage Users, navigate to External User, then locate the person on the list. Click \"Convert to full access'. This person will be added to your subscription.\n\n Q: If I added someone as a **full access **user by mistake but want to make them an **external** user instead, can I do this? \n \n A: Unfortunately, you'll need to remove the user from the workspace and re-invite the user as an External User.\n\n Related Articles Instant Messaging External Users Teams in Hive Hive Notes x Zoom Installation Guide User Permission Roles in Hive  üòû üòê üòÉ \n‚Ä¢ Sign In \n‚Ä¢ Forgot Password? \n‚Ä¢ API \n‚Ä¢ \n‚Ä¢",

          "url": "https://help.hive.com/en/articles/1690862-external-users",
          "content": "External Users | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢ **     User Management External Users \n# External Users\n \nCollaborate with external users on your projects\n Written by Erin Gouveia Updated over 7 months ago  \n External Users app is a Premium App**, if you're interested in the pricing, you can check out our Pricing Page . \n\nUsing Hive's external users, you can invite individuals to collaborate on projects within Hive.**‚Äã\n \nExternal users are limited to the actions and messages within the assigned project and do not have access to your entire workspace. Let's dive into more details on the following topics:\n\n Sending Invitation \n \n‚Ä¢ \n Navigating in Hive as External Users \n \n‚Ä¢ \n How to add an external user \n \n‚Ä¢ \n How to convert an external user to a regular use \n \n‚Ä¢ \n How to remove an external user \n \n‚Ä¢ \n Hiding actions from external users \n \n‚Ä¢ \n Chat & messaging \n \n‚Ä¢ \n What permissions do external users have? \n \n# Sending Invitation\n \n *Note - External Users cannot have the same domain as a Full Access user. **\n \n For Example - Workspace with @hive.com as their email cannot invite an External User who has a @hive.com email address. \n\n## Option 1: Using the Invite button\n \nYou can start the invitation by clicking the \"Invite\" button located at the top right corner of Hive, then select the External option and click Next.\n\nOn the next page, you will be prompted to select which projects to invite External Users to. **External Users must belong to at least one project** when they are invited into Hive.\n\nOnce the invitation has been sent, the External User will receive an email from Hive, and they will be able to click the \"Accept Invitation\" link in the email.\n\nThe link will take the External User to a \"Join your team in Hive\" page, where they can create their account using Google or Microsoft credentials, but they also have the option to set up their account with Email & Password. To do so, they can click the \"Sign Up with work email\" button, fill in their details, and then click Start using Hive.\n\n## Option 2: From a project\n \nGo to the members modal (within the project, click on the project members section on the top left side of the project) \n\nStart typing their name or email address in the 'invite' input \n\nChoose to add them as an external user, Set their access level and click 'Invite' \n\n** Note: ** If you do not have access to invite new members to your Hive workspace, you will not be able to add new external users via the members modal. You will only be able to add existing external users to a new project. \n\n# Navigating in Hive as External Users\n \nWhen External Users open their Hive for the first time, they will land on the Home page. On the left side, they will see the Home page, Apps, and then the projects they have access to. On the right side, they will view Buzz, New, Notifications, their Profile, and then the support button.\n\n# How to convert an external user to a regular user\n \n‚Ä¢ \nGo to your profile dropdown\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSelect **Manage users** \n \n‚Ä¢ \nSelect the External User tab\n \n‚Ä¢ \nFind the external user in the list, select the drop-down on the right and then 'Convert to full access'\n\n# How to remove external users\n \n‚Ä¢ \nFrom the Manage Users tab (see above)\n \n‚Ä¢ \nFind the external user and select 'Remove' from the drop-down next to their name \n\n# Hide Actions from External users\n \nTo make external collaboration even more seamless, you can now toggle on a \" hide action \" setting on specific action cards with a few clicks. This enables total privacy for your organization while allowing you to remain on top of actions and projects.\n\nTo get started, you will first need to enable the Client Mode in project settings. To do that, go to More, then click \"Enable Client Mode\".\n\nOnce this feature is enabled, all actions in the project will have an external users toggle on the top of the card which indicates if the card is either private to the internal team, or visible to external users. All action cards will be private to the internal team by default.\n\n Once the toggle is enabled, external users will be able to see and access the card.\n\n# External Users and Hive Messaging:\n \nExternal Users may direct messages with users that are members of projects where they are also a member.\n\nExternal Users may not be added to group chats, but they will be a member of a group chat created from a project where they are a member.           "content": "Microsoft Office 365 Integration OAuth Scopes | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢ **    Technical Resources Security & SSO Microsoft Office 365 Integration OAuth Scopes \n# Microsoft Office 365 Integration OAuth Scopes\n \nAn overview of OAuth Scopes that Hive requests access to for Microsoft Office 365 Hive Apps Integrations\n A Written by Alexander Heldring Updated over a year ago \n\n### Hive Apps - OneDrive\n \nThe \"OneDrive\" Hive App allows for seamless integration of your Microsoft OneDrive cloud file storage to enable quick browsing and attachment of OneDrive + Sharepoint files onto multiple resources in Hive.\n\nThe scope(s) required for the integration to function are listed below:\n \n Scope**\n \n**Permission**\n \n**How it's used by Hive**\n \nFiles.ReadWrite.All\n \nHave full access to all files user can access\n \nUsed to fetch OneDrive file data for opening the OneDrive file picker. Read access enabled for \"all\" so that users can select and attach any files from their Microsoft OneDrive and Sharepoint site files. Write access enabled so that users can leverage OneDrive file picker upload capabilities to add new files to OneDrive through the picker before attaching into Hive.\n \n### Hive Apps - Calendar (Office 365)\n \nThe \"Calendar\" Hive App allows for seamless integration of your calendar into Hive so that you can easily view a pop-out calendar view from inside of Hive to easily view your schedule, respond/update calendar events, get meeting reminders, open video conferencing, schedule work blocks for Actions, and integrate meeting notes for calendar events before/during/after your meetings.\n\nThe scope(s) required for the integration to function are listed below:\n \n**Scope**\n \n**Permission**\n \n**How it's used by Hive**\n \nCalendars.ReadWrite.Shared\n \nHave full access to user calendars\n \nRead access is used to populate the \"My Day\" interface in Hive with calendar events and details. It is also used to allow syncing of calendar events to Hive Notes. Write access is used to respond to events from \"My Day\" and schedule events from Hive Actions.\n \nShared access is used to help users avoid conflict when using Scheduling.\n\n### Hive Apps - Mail (Office 365)\n \nThe \"Mail\" Hive App allows for seamless integration of your Microsoft 365 email account so you can access your inbox, send new messages, organize email follow-ups, and more , all without ever leaving Hive.\n\nThe scope(s) required for the integration to function are listed below:\n \n**Scope**\n \n**Permission**\n \n**How it's used by Hive**\n \n Files.ReadWrite.All\n \nHave full access to all files user can access\n \nRead access is used to fetch OneDrive file data for adding attachments to emails sent from inside of Hive. Write access is used to upload file attachments which exceed a size which restricts them from being compatible with email standards; large files are instead uploaded to OneDrive and added as an attachment.\n \n Calendars.ReadWrite\n \nHave full access to user calendars\n \nRead access is used to fetch calendar event details in the email client for emails which are meeting invites, allowing dynamic rendering of event details in Hive. Write access is used to respond to events from dynamically rendered emails.\n \nPeople.Read\n \nRead users' relevant people lists\n \nRead access is used to load in contacts when sending emails from inside of Hive such that contacts are auto-populated and searchable as expected for any modern email client.\n \nMail.ReadWrite\n \nRead and write access to user mail\n \nRead access is used to load mailboxes and emails into the email client.           "content": "What is WBS? | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢    Getting Started Importing your work What is WBS? \n# What is WBS?\n \nHow to use work breakdown structure (WBS) to create action hierarchies\n A Written by Alexander Heldring Updated over 2 years ago \nA Work Breakdown Structure (WBS) is a hierarchical decomposition of a project into smaller components. It breaks down a project into manageable chunks and allows project managers to define and organize the scope of their project in an organized manner. A Work Breakdown Structure (WBS) also provides an effective way to track project progress and identify dependencies. ‚Äã\n \nYou can use WBS while importing a CSV to define action hierarchies and/or predecessors. The structure is as follows: \n\naction.subaction...\n\nFor example, if a row had a WBS value of '3.1' that would mean it is the first subaction of the third action in the list. \n\nIf you import a project with the following WBS: \n\nThen in Hive, it will look like this: \n\nNotice that the action with WBS '3.1.1' is the third level in the action hierarchy. Like actions, there is no limit to the amount of nesting that can be created in a work breakdown structure. \n\nWBS also allows us to create dependencies in CSV imports. If you have a 'Predecessor' column in your CSV, you can reference an actions WBS to create a dependency. \n\nIn this example, once the CSV is imported into Hive Action 2 would be dependent on Action 1 and so on. \n\nNote that 'WBS' and 'Predecessor' are optional columns in the CSV import. If WBS is not present, then all rows will be imported as top level actions.           "content": "Plan & execute company initiatives | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢ **     Use Cases Plan & execute company initiatives \n# Plan & execute company initiatives\n \nKeep everyone rowing in the same direction with Hive projects, templates & amazing teamwork\n Written by Erin Gouveia Updated over 5 months ago  \n Company-wide initiatives exist across companies of all types and sizes. Use this quick-start guide to get started in Hive and optimize your project flow and structure.\n\nDo any of these issues sound familiar?\n \nI don't understand the macro-level initiatives my company is planning.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nI don't know who is working on what tasks within a larger projects.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nWhat's the next step after I complete this small task?\n \n‚Ä¢ \nCan I see a high-level view of what's going on in the organization?\n \n# Step 1: Define the Initiative **\n \nIf you can relate to any of the questions above, this article is for you. Let's first think about the types of initiatives your team is taking on. Which of the following are they?\n \n‚Ä¢ \n**Micro-level: On-going, repeatable initiatives that exist within a department** (i.e. HR team onboarding, legal team reviewing materials for sign-off)\n \n‚Ä¢ \n**Macro-level: Department initiatives undergone to achieve KPIs**\n \nGood news -- you can tackle both of these initiatives in Hive. Once you understand the type of initiative you're working on, you can get started on the moving parts and tasks within.\n\nFirst we need to ask ourselves a few questions. To start, we want to better understand how your team has learned about this initiative.\n\nWas it...\n \n‚Ä¢ \nTriggered by an event in the company\n \n‚Ä¢ \nAn ongoing project that your team is running for the company \n \n‚Ä¢ \nA repeatable tasks that exists or pops-up every week\n \n‚Ä¢ \nA response to requests from other teams or departments \n \n‚Ä¢ \nGiven to the team by leadership\n\n# **Step 2: Sketch It Out in Hive**\n \nOnce we understand what triggered the event, we can take the appropriate actions in Hive. \n\n**If the task was triggered by an event in the company:**\n \n‚Ä¢ \nCreate a new project in Hive for the initiative or task and invite all relevant team members from your organization.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nTo add a new project, click the \"New\" button in the upper right-hand corner of your Hive window and select New Project.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nYou'll need to add teammates to your project. To do this, click the \"Edit Project\" button in Hive and press the \"Add project members\". They'll now be able to access and visualize this initiative.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIf there are relevant documents or additional information, you can attach them in the Project Overview. Access Project Overview by clicking the Overview button when you're inside the project.\n \nAnother component of Hive that you might want to utilize if a task is triggered by an event in the company is Sections.\n\nEvery project goes through a process from start to finish. In some industries, this process is marked by stages. For example, a consulting project might have three section: planning, execution, and closing.\n \n**To use sections in Hive:\n \n‚Ä¢ \nWhen adding sections to a new project **, go to the project navigator, select \"+ New Project\", create the project, click More menu at the top right corner, then scroll down to find the Section, then click \"Add section\".\n \n‚Ä¢ \nWhen you create a new action, it ** adds it to the New section by default **. You change an action's section by clicking the dropdown menu at the top of the action card.\n \nOnce you've set up Sections, you can use them in a few ways:\n \n‚Ä¢ \nFilter all actions in Kanban by status\n \n‚Ä¢ \nView actions broken down by sections in Gantt view\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIn Gantt view, you can also group actions by section\n \n**If the task is an ongoing project that your team is running for the company:**\n \n‚Ä¢ \nThis setup is going to look largely the same as the previous, except you will be adding tasks to a preexisting project.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIf you need to add team members to the project, click the \"Edit Project\" button in Hive and add \"Members\" to your project.       "full_guide_content": "Manage complex project timelines | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢ **     Use Cases Manage complex project timelines \n# Manage complex project timelines\n \nAn powerful tool for the PMO & the PMO within all of us\n Written by Erin Gouveia Updated over 2 months ago  \nHive has everything you need to manage large-scale, multi-workstream project plans and with this get-started guide, we'll have your timeline loaded into Hive in no time.\n\nLet's get started!\n\n# Step 1: Where is your project plan now? **\n \n**a) It's in another tool & I'm planning to import it**\n \nGreat, hop over to our Import Guide to review the steps, and come back here once you've imported it\n\n**b) I'm starting from scratch**\n \nOk, let's get you started by creating a New Project (New > Project) with:\n \nTitle\n \n‚Ä¢ \nDue date\n \n‚Ä¢ \nGantt layout\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSections: hold off for now, we will get to that next\n \n‚Ä¢ \nShared with: we recommend starting with just yourself for now, but our Draft Mode works well if you'd like to add your teammates but not notify them of assignments until you're finished with the plan. \n \n**Tip:** once your project is created, click the configure menu to change the available columns and filters\n\n# **Step 2: Map out the workstreams **\n \n## How does your project naturally 'break down':\n \n**a) By major Stage or Sections of work, with individual steps within these sections owned by specific teams or departments**\n \nIf this is the case, we recommend that you set up Sections within your project to be those major lifecycle stages that everything in your project can be categorized into.\n\nSections are added by going to More > Edit Project > and adding the sections there.\n\nYou can then enter actions into the sections, when you group by section or drag existing actions into your sections:\n\n**b) By Workstream or Department: each team runs their own segment of this overall project and we don't organize into the same lifecycle stage across all work streams. **\n\nIn this case, we recommend that if your Department work streams are more than 30 specific tasks, that these be all labeled the same, and then you view your timeline grouped by Label rather than by Section. Head to the Invites section to invite everyone who is responsible to complete a part of this project plan . \n\nRemember, your internal team members within your organization would be regular members, while external parties who may need access to a single project or who are outside of your organization, could be External Users . \n\nWith everyone assigned out their work, it's time to begin! üìà\n\nOnce work is assigned, team members can refer to their My Actions page to see their action and task assignments across all of their projects.\n\n# **Step 6: Gain Approval for Deliverables**\n \nIf your deliverables need to go through an internal or external review process, leverage the proofing and approval capabilities in Hive to receive feedback and track approvals.\n\nUpload files for review in the Hive Proofing tool where multiple team members can simultaneously conduct a review, adding comments and markups in real-time.\n\nCreate approval routes that go to multiple users, teams, as well as external approvers (those without Hive accounts).\n\nWhen it's your turn to review, you'll receive a notification and the request for your approval will appear on your My Actions page to easily tracker all of your approval requests.\n\n# **For additional power-ups, we recommend:**\n \n‚Ä¢ \nKicking off the project with Running a Great Meeting \n \n‚Ä¢ \nKeeping track of key dates in Portfolio View \n \n‚Ä¢ \nNoting any major concerns through our Risks & Issues Tracker \n Related Articles Gantt charts Plan & execute company initiatives New this Week in Hive: June 2021 List View: A New Project View in Hive Home View: List View (New)!  üòû üòê üòÉ \n‚Ä¢ Sign In \n‚Ä¢ Forgot Password? \n‚Ä¢ API \n‚Ä¢ \n‚Ä¢",

      "full_guide_content": "Run a modern agency on Hive | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢ **     Use Cases Run a modern agency on Hive \n# Run a modern agency on Hive\n \nLeverage Hive to enable your Agency workflow from end to end\n Written by Dee Miller Updated over a year ago  \nHive can support every step in your campaign lifecycle from brief to progress reporting. With our step by step guide you can get your campaigns set up ready to go, tracking included. \n\nLet's get started!\n\n# Step 1: How do your work requests, campaigns or projects begin? Let‚Äôs build a seamless work request and briefing system for you.**\n \nWhen initiating projects or campaigns, work generally begins with a brief or request. Create a ** Hive Form ** to capture the request and move away from inconsistent email and duplicate documents. Hive offers you the option of creating an action card in an intake project, ready for triage or creating a project directly from the submission. \n\nTypes of request great for Hive forms:\n \nNew client brief submission\n \n‚Ä¢ \nCreative resource or support requests\n \n‚Ä¢ \nAd hoc client requests\n \n‚Ä¢ \nAd Ops Trafficking\n \nHere is an example of a creative resource request and a new campaign brief:\n\n**Hive Form to Action card **\n\nIn the below example, the Hive Form is used to collect resource requests for a creative team. The Hive form is creating an action card with the request details for additional resource and landing this in a specific project ready for the triage and assignment:\n\n**Hive Form to Project** \n\nIn the below example, the Hive Form collects the briefing information and creates a campaign from a template, ready for the media team to start work. \n\n# **Step 2: Set up your Project Navigator and utilise Project Custom Fields for specific campaign information. **\n \nThe project structure must reflect how you organize and execute work. Hive provides you with the flexibility to create a ** project hierarchy **that‚Äôs right for you and your team. \n\nDetermine the structure that‚Äôs right for your team by thinking about how the work is structured:\n \n‚Ä¢ \nLine of business\n \n‚Ä¢ \nChannel\n \n‚Ä¢ \nProject-based\n \n‚Ä¢ \nCampaign-based\n\n**Top Tip:** Create specific guidelines for your Hive users to explain any require naming conventions for your campaigns or projects when applying a template or creating a project. \n\n**Project Custom Fields**\n\nFor custom campaign data that you‚Äôd like to track and see displayed on the Project Navigator, project views and included in the Portfolio view, setting up ** Project Custom Fields ** can be incredibly useful. \n\nCampaign data can include:\n \n‚Ä¢ \nCampaign Budget\n \n‚Ä¢ \nChannel\n \n‚Ä¢ \nCampaign Tier\n \n‚Ä¢ \nClient name\n \n‚Ä¢ \nClient line of business or product\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSLA details\n \n‚Ä¢ \nExec Sponsor\n\nHere's how to set one up:\n \n‚Ä¢ \nGo to the project where you want to add a custom field\n \n‚Ä¢ \nGo to the 'More' menu in the upper right\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSelect 'Create custom field'\n \n‚Ä¢ \nType the name of the field you want to add, select the field kind & type\n \n‚Ä¢ \nHit 'Save'.\n\n# **Step 3: Create a non-campaign or ad-hoc projects to capture tasks outside of your campaigns; support this with a label for easy reporting. **\n \nFrom time to time, tasks and work will occur that is outside of the campaign template. It can help track these for review, assignment or including in your campaign update or QBR with clients.\n\nWe recommend creating an Ad Hoc ** project ** where team members can create action cards corresponding to any non-campaign or ad-hoc work requests at a client or channel level. \n\nDoing this will allow you visibility into additional work requests that may be aligned to your organisation‚Äôs channels but not specific to any client. At the same time, a client-specific project will give visibility to client-related ad hoc tasks. \n\n**Top Tip:** Create a Hive label that can be applied to all ad-hoc tasks; this will enable you to leverage a Summary view to report all non-campaign tasks across your portfolio. See the next step on how to create labels. \n\n# **Step 4: Create your labels to categorize work across your campaigns **\n \nWith ** labels **, you can categorize your actions across projects. By creating labels for channels, organization groups, regions or any vital information you would like to group actions and tasks across campaigns or projects, you can easily create a report with a summary view. \n\nLabel data can support:\n \n‚Ä¢ \nA Summary View of all work sent to an off-shore hub\n \n‚Ä¢ \nAll actions within a specific channel across all campaigns\n \n‚Ä¢ \nAll Ad-hoc or non-campaign work-in-progress or complete for a particular client. \n \nJust like an action, you can also create labels with relationships. This gives you more organization and flexibility in categorizing your actions. For example, you may wish to create labels for your channels and group them by region. \n\nHere is how to create your labels:\n \n‚Ä¢ \nNavigate to your profile menu, and click on Workspace settings\n \n‚Ä¢ \nGo to the ‚ÄúLabels‚Äù tab and create a new label\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSelect the parent label for any labels which you wish to nest under a parent label\n\n# **Step 5: Utilize project templates for quick campaign set-up and action templates for processes to support campaign delivery. **\n \n**Project Templates**\n\nCreating ** project templates ** speeds up your work by allowing you to predefine your campaign plan with the settings, structure and specific steps you need to take in a particular type of campaign or project. Project templates give you the benefit of templating sections, labels, actions, subactions, assignees, custom fields and durations.\n\nRemember that a template has the same qualities as a project, so take advantage and add extras to the template to best represent your campaigns (labels, milestones, etc.) so you can save time once you kick off a live campaign. By including milestones to define KPIs in your template, you will be able to leverage Hive‚Äôs Portfolio view and Summary Views to deliver detailed campaign reports based on critical milestones throughout the campaign lifecycle. \n\nProject templates are great for: \n \n‚Ä¢ \nCreative campaign set-up\n \n‚Ä¢ \nE2E campaign timelines\n \n‚Ä¢ \nClient onboarding projects\n \n‚Ä¢ \nChannel Specific campaigns\n \n**Top Tip: **If you have your campaign plan, SLAs or E2E Lifecycle in CSV, it can be quickly uploaded to Hive and ready to go rapidly. \n\n**Top Tip #2:** Ensure you have a project-level due date on your template that correlates to one of the template‚Äôs action due dates. Choose a new due date when applying the template, and all dates will shift according to that date. If no due date is on the template when applied, dates/durations of actions will not carry over. \n\n**How to create a new template**\n \n‚Ä¢ \nNavigate to the 'Templates' tab on the Project Navigator\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSelect '+ New Project Template'\n \n‚Ä¢ \nBuild the template like you would a project (name, dates, labels, description, attachments, sections)\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSelect who you'd like to share the template with & its permission settings\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSelect the default layout for the template\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSelect 'Create template'\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSee the template in the 'Templates' tab\n \n‚Ä¢ \nBuild out the template as you would a project (you can add actions and subactions and include start and due dates, assignees, labels, etc.) \n\n**Action Templates**\n\nCreating ** action templates ** speeds up your work by allowing you to predefine the specific steps you need to take in a particular type of task. Applying an action template to an action auto-populates a set of subactions. You can build action templates with labels, assignees, dependencies and ** deadlines **. \n\nAction templates are great for: \n \n‚Ä¢ \nReports \n \n‚Ä¢ \nCreative approvals\n \n‚Ä¢ \nQA rounds\n \n‚Ä¢ \nCampaign briefing \n \n‚Ä¢ \nFinancial reconciliation\n\n# **Step 6: Create your Teams in Hive**\n \nManaging many users is made easy by creating a team in Hive to represent the teams and working groups across your organization. By adding a team to a project every time the team is updated, project members of all projects where the team is a member will be auto-updated. You can add teams to projects, summary views, templates, group chats, comments and tasks within your workspace. This ensures you have the right Hive project members added to the correct campaigns to get to work faster. \n\nHere‚Äôs how to create and manage your ** Hive teams **:\n\nTo create a team, go to the \"Manage users\" tab in your workspace settings. You can find this by going to 'Your Profile Dropdown' > 'Manage Users' > 'Teams'. \n \nSelect \"Teams\" to search existing teams, Edit or Delete existing teams, or create new teams. \n \n**Note:** Only admins or the creator of the team will be able to Edit/Delete teams. \n\nThe \"+Create new team\" button will open the following options where you can enter a team name and select workspace members to be part of the team.\n\nTo edit your team click the edit pen icon, and you will be able to amend the membership and name of your team. \n\n# **Step 7: Build a Summary View for teamwork assignments & Status.**\n \n** Summary Views **are a great way to combine several projects into one view. It's handy for managers and those who want to take a look at the bigger picture across the team. \n\nExamples of leveraging summary views:\n \n‚Ä¢ \nWhen you have a team status meeting and need to pull a report of all work within your client or channel team. A summary view set to table view focused on your client team in Hive or channel label including all projects will return a detailed report of all tasks for your status meeting. This view can also be sorted by the due date to identify the most pressing tasks.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nWhen working with your team to assess workload, use a summary view set to team view showing all active campaigns to pull a report across your team to identify who has the capacity to help support when a team member has too much work on deadline. \n\n# **Step 8: Create a Portfolio view to track live campaigns **\n \n** Portfolio View **is the all-in-one place to see the detail set out in Project Navigator combined with a Table View‚Äôs flexibility.       "full_guide_content": "Run great meetings | Hive Help \n‚Ä¢ **     Use Cases Run great meetings \n# Run great meetings\n \nUtilize Hive to meet more efficiently.\n Written by Erin Gouveia Updated over 4 years ago  \nMeetings are at the core of the modern workweek. Could it just be an email?\n \n‚Ä¢ \nHow can I make sure that the meetings we conduct are actually productive with everyone working from home?\n \n‚Ä¢ \nHow can I be sure that everyone actually does what they say they'll do before our next sync?\n \nHive has got you covered. In this article, we'll walk through how to optimize your Hive experience to run the best possible meetings and ensure timely and efficient follow-ups. A stellar meeting is a few minutes away.\n\n# Step 1: Create a Hive Note for your meeting**\n \n**Every great meeting starts with an agenda**. Prepare for the most productive meeting of your life by using Hive Notes to create an agenda and share the note with your teammates. To get started with Hive notes:\n \n‚Ä¢ \nClick on \"Notes\" in the bottom right hand corner of Hive to open the Notes panel.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nClick \"New Note\" to create a new note.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nAssign the Note to a project and any new actions created from the Note will map into that project automatically.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nAdd your agenda items to the note and share with your team by clicking on the \"Share\" button on the note's upper right-hand corner. Additionally, the meeting Note can be sent externally as an email to leadership or clients.\n\n# **Step 2: Kick the Meeting Off**\n \nYou've sent around the agenda, and now it's time to kick off the meeting. That's where Hive's Zoom integration comes into play. To ensure that your Zoom account is linked to Hive, complete the following steps:\n \n‚Ä¢ \nVisit \"Hive Apps\" in the left-hand panel navigation section of Hive\n \n‚Ä¢ \nToggle on the Zoom integration tile, and enter your Zoom details\n \n**Now it's time to start the meeting in Hive, and there are a few ways to do that:**\n\nGo to the messaging group, or direct message, where you want to start a meeting. From there, you can start a meeting in a few ways:\n \n‚Ä¢ \nType \"/zoom\" in the group or direct message. A Zoom meeting will automatically be started.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nClick on the Zoom icon on the top right corner of your messaging window.\n \n‚Ä¢ \nIn the messaging input box, click the + button and select \"Create Zoom Meeting.\"\n\n# **Step 3: Assign Next Steps**\n\nOnce you're in the meeting, you can utilize the Notes collaborative functionality to add notes, next steps, and action items into the Note itself. \n\nTo add an action item into the Note and assign it as a next step, simply select all text that you would like to make a next step and click on the check mark on the bottom left hand corner of the formatting box.\n\nNext, you can assign the next step to someone on your team by clicking on the assignee section and selecting a team member from the dropdown. You can also easily assign a due date.\n\n# **Step 4: Link your note to a calendar event **\n \nWant to quickly capture the attendee list and meeting logistics? You can easily do that by syncing your calendar with Hive. \n \n**To enable Hive Calendar, visit the Apps section on the left-hand tool bar and select Hive Apps. Hive Calendar is an available app listed here. Toggle it on, and sign in to your email account and authorize the connection. \n\nOnce enabled, go back to your note and link it to your meeting. Hive will populate all the meeting details for you! \n\n# Step 5: Follow-up with Teammates and turn your ad hoc emails into actions in your project**\n \nNeed to follow-up with teammates or external parties after the meeting? You can do that from inside Hive with Hive Mail.\n\nTo enable Hive Mail , visit the aforementioned Apps section on the left-hand tool bar and select Hive Apps. Hive Mail is an available app listed here. Toggle it on, and sign in to your email account, authorize the connection, and you'll be all set!\n\nThe opportunities with Hive Mail are limitless. In addition to following up on any Notes and next steps assigned, you can also:\n\n**Turn your email into an action card in Hive**\n\nActions you create from an email will be private and assigned to you by default, and the email thread will live in the action card.\n\nTo create an action from an email, click into the email from your Hive Mail inbox, then click the checkmark icon above the message. You‚Äôll then be able to access it from My Actions.\n\n**Link emails to existing actions**\n\nReceive an email that‚Äôs relevant to your meeting, or something you‚Äôre already working on? You can link emails to existing actions as well! To do so, click into the email from your Hive Mail inbox, then click the link icon above the message. This will embed the email thread into your action card.\n\n**Reply or forward messages right from your action cards**\n\nNo need to hop from action card to inbox. Anyone who has access to the action card will be able to view and reply to the linked messages, ensuring that everyone stays up to date with the latest.\n\nThese tips are just a few of the ways you can utilize Hive to run your most efficient meetings. (This sends the user a notification)\n\n# **Step 3: Do you resource by team? **\n \n## Do your team members have assigned teams that you may want to quickly filter to - i.e., show me the Design Team's workload?\n\n**Yes? ** Create teams & set all employees' teams in the Workspace Setting: click on your profile icon, click Settings, navigate to Teams, click the blue \"Create new team\"\n\n# **Step 4: Does your team have specific roles or special skills?**\n \na) Yes! Great, you can go to the Resourcing Setting, go to People, search for a user, click on their name, and then you'll be able to update the user role or User Tag.\n\nIf you require a user‚Äôs role to be modified for a particular project, the Admin or Project Owner can make the necessary adjustments on the Overview page.\n\nb) No, teams is specific enough for my resourcing view. --> No action needed!\n\n# **Step 5: Do you need to allocate time before you know who can take on the work?**\n \nIf so, Placeholders are going to assist in making this possible. User availability is determined based on the user‚Äôs Work week hours. This section can be accessed by going to Resourcing > User Profile.\n\nIf the user‚Äôs workweek hours are not provided, Hive will utilize the Threshold value specified in the Resourcing settings. The action template can be applied when a request is submitted to ensure that you have all the correct information to hand as soon as the request arrives in your queue. \n\nHere is how to create your labels:\n \nNavigate to your profile menu, and click on Workspace settings\n \n‚Ä¢ \nGo to the ‚ÄúLabels‚Äù tab and create a new label\n \n‚Ä¢ \nSelect the parent label for any labels which you wish to nest under a parent label\n\n# **Step 5: Create an action template to populate recurring actions, deadlines, labels and assignments**\n \nTo quickly get your teams to work, template recurring tasks that should be followed for each work request with an ** action template .** \n\nThis enables you to add relevant labels, automatically assign work to team members, ensure ** deadlines ** are presented correctly in line with your SLA and provide a consistent workflow for progress reporting and work capacity management. \n\n# **Step 6: Set up custom status in the status view to reflect the stages of your workflow**\n \nA custom ** status ** can reflect specific stages in your workflow; on Hold, With Client, or QA are helpful examples of custom status that can be employed to help report on the status of work and communication with project teams. \n\n# **Step 7: Connect Hive mail to quickly follow up on form submissions**\n \n** Hive mail ** enables you to attach email strings to existing work requests to support fast follow-ups, confirmations and proactively seeing additional information to help workflow smoothly. You can create an email, reply or forward emails directly from within your action card.\n\n# **Step 8: Consider Card priorities level options to help your teams prioritize work requests.**\n \nWant to make sure your teams address high priority items first? Utilize ** Priority Levels ** in Hive and customize it to meet your specific needs. \n\n# **Step 9: Build a Summary View for teamwork assignments & Status.**\n \n Summary Views are a great way to combine several projects into one view.
